I hope Sir Julius Chan can take another new initiative and can again commence negotiations with the leaders of the BRA, to find another mechanism by which the peace process can be pursued, and that normalcy in health, education and all community facilities can proceed.

Without doubt, Bougainville is one of the richest provinces of PNG. There is every reason for it to be able to restore itself to a peaceful condition, without the traumas that have beset the place, for what seemed to be no good reason, over the past few years. I know that that really was one of the objectives of those of us who were on that mission to PNG. I hope that that initiative will not be totally forestalled because of the problems. In this report, we have made a number of recommendations which need to be picked up by the Australian government and, hopefully, by the government of PNG, for I think they will go part of the way to recommencing the process of restoring peace to Bougainville.

Finally, I was very disappointed to see that Senator Dee Margetts has added a minority report to this report. I thought it added nothing. I thought it demonstrated that she is not prepared to be part of the normal political process. All of us have to accept compromise. The objective of trying to secure human rights should be above the prejudices of individuals. To my mind, having one person come out and say that she does not agree, as she has, demonstrates how difficult it is to achieve peace around the world. Senator Margetts sat with us and contributed at every meeting and she participated in the other decisions. But when it was all over she came out and said, `I do not agree with it anyway.' This demonstrates to me that, while we have people such as Senator Dee Margetts, there is little hope for those of us trying to achieve what we thought was a worthwhile objective.(Time expired)

TALK.START.PARA: —Thomas Jefferson once said that the execution of the laws was more important than the making of them. For a law-maker who believes strongly in the importance of the rule of law, and by no means wishing to undermine my own role, I approve of this statement. For the past 18 months, the Human Rights Subcommittee has considered the implementation of the human rights standards which have been defined over the past 50 years by the United Nations. There are of course standards which have underpinned government practice in many societies for much longer than that.

PARA.TAB: I recognise that judging matters of policy for promoting and protecting human rights is fraught with difficulty. This is partly because judgments are hard to make, especially in a short time and at a distance from the circumstances. It is also partly because there are many paradoxes inherent in the possible solutions to problems. When is action better than negotiation? When is intervention advisable? Can peacemaking prolong the misery and exacerbate the suffering? When are laws relating to child labour detrimental to family welfare? To what extent is our motivation affected by self-interest rather than altruism?

I believe that the challenge for Australia is to hold steadfastly to what we know to be good in our own practice; to propound it with firm politeness and self-assurance; and to listen, debate and discuss the insights of our neighbours with open curiosity as to the true nature of their experience. Central to the effective protection of human rights is the rule of law. This needs some explanation as there is no shortage of legislation in the world, much of it high sounding. By the rule of law, I mean law that is made by democratically elected assemblies; laws interpreted by an independent judiciary; and laws executed by police forces with high ethical standards, uncorrupted by the wealthy and the powerful.

While the separation of powers that underlies this is a particular device of Western political theory, the justice that it ensures is universally understood and universally desired. Therefore, Australia's efforts to promote the rule of law—whether it be through the aid program, through the work of the International Commission of Jurists, through the defence cooperation program or through peacemaking—is to be applauded.

The committee took 81 hours of evidence at public hearings. As was to be expected, there has been comment, most of it favourable, but some critical, such as the comment from Senator Kemp. Senator Kemp's criticism of the report, made in the Senate on Monday, was an exercise in overstatement, a distortion of any argument. No doubt his criticism emanated from his dissatisfaction with the fact that the committee did not accept many of the assumptions underlying his submission. In the debate on Monday, in the Senate, he claimed that the report showed that there were serious problems with the treaty making procedures. This is not so. The report believed there were minor adjustments that could be made to the process and that some existing processes could be streamlined, not only by the Commonwealth but also by the states.

Senator Kemp denigrates the government's enormous enthusiasm for treaties as if it is an evil plot by an evil empire. This, I think, says more about his own conspiratorial outlook on the world. The number of treaties is a reflection of the interconnectedness of the modern world. Therefore, what he describes as a sovereignty problem conceded in the first report was not that at all.

That committee, of which I was a member, did not believe there was a sovereignty problem. It saw the limitations on national sovereignty rather as matters of fact, an inevitable consequence of an interdependent world, and the extended accountability beyond the usual domestic constituency as a necessary, useful and valuable thing in a world so bedevilled by many governments' abuse of their citizens.

It must be noted here that the limitations on national sovereignty remain voluntary acts of nation states. In the human rights area, they need never impinge on states whose laws are sound and whose record of protection of the rights of citizens is thoroughgoing.

The current report does not dismiss the notion of sovereignty. It considered the arguments carefully. It agreed with Senator Kemp that it was preferable that the human rights complaints of Australians be dealt with by Australian courts. Hence it recommended the consideration of the introduction of a bill of rights to complement the ICCRP in Australian law and thereby circumvent any need for Australian citizens to take complaints to the Human Rights Committee in Geneva. Good national practice is the aim of human rights treaties.

While the quoted passages of the views of Sir Ninian Stephen alert us to the dangers inherent in any international system, Sir Ninian, nevertheless, appeared to accept, as does the report, the necessary and beneficial aspects of internationalism. The comments of Sir Ninian are as much a confirmation of as a contrast to those of the committee. The committee too believes it is timely that parliament be involved in the treaty making process, and we have said so.

The committee addressed seriously all the questions on the role of parliament, the role of states and the consultative mechanisms. It neither lacked courage nor ignored the issues. However, the evidence before the committee did not confirm the position put to it by Senator Kemp. The states were consulted on treaties and often included delegations for negotiations of treaties. It seemed to the committee that the fault, if fault there be, of any failure to understand the importance of treaties lay as much in the mechanisms and the efforts made at the state government level as at the Commonwealth government level. It also appeared to the committee that on occasions state governments which had been parties to the process chose to deny their responsibilities for parochial political reasons.

The comments made by people regarding the United Nations are also interesting. I listened with great interest to what the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) said about this earlier. People speak of the United Nations as an entity, as an `it'. The United Nations is a collection of sovereign states, not an entity in its own right. If a change to the United Nations system is needed, and it could well be, the ability to do so lies with the sovereign states who make up its membership. As I say, I have no argument with the view that the United Nations needs to be streamlined but, if it is going to be streamlined, it will be the sovereign states who make up its membership. It will not be the United Nations itself—not the `it'—but the entity of the sovereign states which makes up its membership which will put this streamline process into action.

A word needs to be said about the minority view at the end of the report which the right honourable member for New England also mentioned. I make this comment not because it is a substantial or considered document but because the tone of it is highly offensive. It is full of simplistic, self-righteousness and smug condescension—the kind of thing that gives human rights a bad name.

There are two particular areas I will comment on: the committee process and politics. Senator Margetts's comments on what the committee did not do purport to be the comments of an insider to the workings of the Human Rights Subcommittee. This was not so. She did not attend any of the hundreds of hours of meetings and briefings of the committee. She did not listen to the evidence nor did she participate in the discussions on how the committee would approach the masses of information it received in the limited time frame and with very limited resources. Failure to participate in the work of an inquiry usually causes most members of the joint committee to be a little circumspect and reticent in any comments they make at the end of the process.

The Human Rights Subcommittee is asked to review Australian government policy, not the human rights circumstances of the world. Senator Margetts's complaints about what was not covered are ignorant of the terms of reference and the evidence. They are ignorant of the committee process, which is confined to specific evidence presented to it and to a very limited time frame.

A committee inquiry is to look at what is and how that might be moved within the political framework that we have. It is a reflection of the views of those Australians who choose to put in submissions and the committee's response to them. If views are not forthcoming, the committee cannot invent them. It was always possible for Senator Margetts to put in a submission to the committee on matters of concern to her. Other senators did. When Senator Margetts was asked to provide a recommendation on the rights of women, which she complained was not there, it was not provided.

Her arguments on defence cooperation and trade, as with much of her paper, are high on sentiment and low on logic. She claims that too much attention has been given to them—300 to 400 words in 100,000 words. It is simply untrue to suggest that the committee saw them as ends in themselves. They are considered in the report only as they contribute or otherwise to the promotion of human rights. If, as she claims, defence force regimes are the chief perpetrators of human rights abuses, all the more reason to inform them.

On questions of particular human rights situations in other parts of the world, Senator Margetts reveals something of her own methodology. It lacks academic and political wisdom. The committee was not in a position to make definitive pronouncements. To suggest that an Australian parliamentary committee, with a staff of two, should solicit information about every human rights violation around the world, assess it, verify it, and write about it, as well as deal with the terms of reference of the committee to review Australian government policy, all in the space of a year, is nothing short of ludicrous. Bougainville and Burma have been and will be the subject of specific reports by the committee. Without specific inquiry, the committee was not prepared to make extensive comment and confined itself deliberately to thematic commentary based on some of the incidents which some Australians brought to its attention.

Senator Margetts condemns the document as a political document. Who does she think she is? Where does she think she is from? Politics is about compromise. The alternative is bomb throwing. It is politics and political compromises which in our type of country have moved the social agenda peacefully, not always evenly but relentlessly, towards a better life for most citizens. Politics is about keeping your eyes on your agenda, your own constituency, the demands of your party, the strength of the opposition; it is about persuading and cajoling, often in the chamber with aggression, but in committees with humour and with tact. It is about getting what you can for the moment and moving on from there next time. In particular, it is not about alienating those who might be your supporters but about knowing when you have won something.

Of course there were compromises in some areas. I wanted the report to go further once or twice and sometimes I thought we went too far, but, like all other members of the Human Rights Subcommittee, I wanted, if possible, a unanimous report which could encompass the very diverse views of the members who sat through hours of hearings, read thousands of words of submissions, and who each in their own way have a definite and for most of us a longstanding commitment to the protection and promotion of human rights. All of the committee members serve on other committees, but for most of us this was the most important, as we are dealing with the rights of people, including in some cases the right to life. A real difficulty for all of us is that we do not have the time to do all we have wanted.

There are those who will criticise the report, but I believe it has been an outstanding report. I said previously that human rights is fraught with obstacles, hypocrisy, national interest and ideological conflicts. In spite of these problems, the progress of global human rights has been advanced through the actions and dreams of individuals. The struggle for the need to observe human rights, despite the various international conventions, continues in many countries around the world. These include those who adopted them but as yet are unable or unwilling to implement the full extent of these rights within their domains.

Pursuing the question of which rights are universal is a fruitless exercise, since all civilised states have accepted the need for them, as seen in the appointment of the UN Commissioner for Human Rights. The real problem is the perception of dominance and power between alignments of states and perhaps an unwillingness of states to accept the changing post-Cold War world. It remains to be said that a number of differences have more to do with the struggle, both domestic and international, for political power and influence between the players than the issue of human rights per se.

The primary aim in achieving human rights or dignity should be seen as a struggle for achieving justice in every country. If all countries are committed to the idea that human rights are evolving and justice is the ultimate aim, it is not unlikely that a common set of rights will eventually evolve for all mankind. Perhaps that is an unrealistic dream, but it is one certainly worth striving for.

In conclusion, I would like to pay a particular tribute to the chair of the committee, Senator Loosley, who brought a real commitment to the protection of human rights to the committee. If we think the other committee members put in many hours, Senator Loosley put in more than most. The person the greatest tribute should go to is Margaret Swieringa. We all say how many submissions we read. She read and analysed them all for us. For one person, with a support staff, to be mainly responsible for the report is nothing short of outstanding. I pay tribute to the outstanding role that Margaret Swieringa played during the many hours of hearing and the compilation of the report. I commend the report to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As a member of the Human Rights Subcommittee of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, I am delighted to have this opportunity provided today to comment on the report A review of Australia's efforts to promote and protect human rights that was tabled earlier this week in the House of Representatives. Before I move on to the specific recommendations that I would like to talk about this morning, I would like to make two introductory remarks. Firstly, I would like to support fully the comments of my colleague the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) in his criticism of the minority report that has been reported by Senator Margetts. I agree with all of his comments. I believe that the way in which Senator Margetts has written the minority report and the contents of it are totally inappropriate and unreasonable. I support what the honourable member for Throsby has said.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I would like to join with him in congratulating the chair of the committee, Senator Stephen Loosley, who has done an outstanding job. I did not get to participate in as many of the hearings as I would have liked, but I attended a number. Participating in hearings of the Human Rights Subcommittee is a very difficult process. Hour after hour, day after day we were presented with some very gruesome stories about abuses of human rights, suffering and torture that are occurring around the world and the struggles that a lot of people have around the world. It can be an extremely painful and difficult process listening to what is happening around the world and seeing the suffering that a lot of people face.

Senator Loosley, as chair, demonstrated an enormous amount of compassion, concern and sincere commitment to human rights in all of those hearings. He also had a great deal of fortitude in being able to stay there day after day, hearing after hearing, listening to all of the evidence and continuing to be a very strong supporter and a very compassionate person. My sincere congratulations go to Senator Loosley.

I also join with the honourable member for Throsby in supporting his comments about Margaret Swieringa, who has done an outstanding job. The greatest credit a person can give to Margaret is the fact that this document is a very substantial report. It adds to the significant body of evidence and information about human rights and the important role Australia can play in promoting human rights. It will be recognised internationally as a substantial document, not only because of its size, with 63 recommendations and 350 pages, but also because the content of it is very important and valuable. The recommendations are very sensible, sound recommendations that will advance the cause of human rights if they are all implemented, and I sincerely hope they will be.

There are a couple of minor clarifications that we need to make in a couple of the recommendations. I have been asked to make them. They are only very small points but I would like to get their clarification on the public record. The first is in chapter 7, where we are talking about Aboriginal concerns; there is a word left out in recommendation No. 30. We said:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that:

.Aboriginal communities are encouraged to mobilise local skills and resources in cooperation with neighbouring communities and other people who are available to train Aborigines within a community: and
.by way of improving and increasing resources to outback communities, the Commonwealth Government encourage the private sector and/or NGOs to sponsor workers . . .
The word that is left out is `environmental'. It should have continued:
. . . in the fields of environmental health, education, building or community development . . .

Our concern was to support and increase the number of environmental health workers that are available in Aboriginal communities to assist in things such as: cleaning up drainage and rubbish disposal on local communities; constructing housing; supplying appropriate sources of water; making sure water supplies are kept clean—things like that. So the workers were to be environmental health workers.

PARA.TAB: The second clarification I would like to make is with recommendation No. 32. It concerns the lack of ability for Aboriginal people to access banking facilities in a lot of communities. They are not able to deposit their moneys, establish savings accounts, manage their affairs like Aboriginal people or any other Australians are able to do in provincial cities or metropolitan areas. The committee has recommended that the government investigate, and the words in the recommendation are `credit facilities'. That is a little misleading. We are not actually suggesting that they should be given credit facilities—access or capacity to borrow money—but we are suggesting they should have the capacity to save and bank money and to have access to normal banking facilities. So we are in fact referring to saving and banking facilities in recommendation No. 32.

As I said, there were 63 recommendations in this report and I cannot comment on all of them, much as I would like to. There are about half a dozen recommendations I would like to draw to the attention of the Main Committee and the government because I believe these are important ones. The first one I would like to talk about is recommendation No. 5. It refers to the committee's support for the concept of a United Nations parliamentary assembly. One of my other jobs in this parliament is to convene a group called Parliamentarians for Global Action which is—

TALK.START.PARA: —You do it very well indeed.

—Thank you. It is a group of international parliamentarians from some 70 countries around the world. They have a strong belief that, side by side with the General Assembly, which is the coming together of the government representatives of all of the nations which are members of the United Nations, we need to have a parliamentary assembly that can operate to give advice to those government representatives and to the United Nations organisations about what the political representatives of the peoples of the world think about the various issues that are facing the United Nations.

PARA.TAB: I am not suggesting in any way that that should undermine the authority or the sovereignty of the nations that make up the United Nations because I understand that it is a council of sovereign nations; but I do believe that it would be a very valuable source of advice, information and support for the United Nations. It would ensure not only that there were better ideas flowing into the United Nations about what the peoples of the world think should happen and how we should be dealing with peace and disarmament, environmental degradation and all those other important issues, but also it would go the other way and help improve the knowledge about the United Nations and the work of the United Nations in those parliaments and in those nations.

By being there at the United Nations General Assembly, by having their own assembly, by being able to contribute to those debates, parliamentarians could then come back to their national parliaments and better inform their colleagues and tell the peoples they represent what the United Nations is doing and what role ordinary people can play.

So I think the support for a United Nations parliamentary assembly is very important. I think it has widespread support amongst the parliaments around the world. I know that next year, with the 50th anniversary of the founding of the United Nations, the Inter-Parliamentary Union is having its conference as a parliamentary assembly at the United Nations. It will be held in the United Nations during the General Assembly. I hope that this will be the forerunner of many such annual parliamentary assemblies.

I refer now to recommendations 10 and 11, which concern the process of better informing this parliament of our work on human rights and our capacity as a nation to achieve our obligations under UN treaties and conventions. Recommendation No. 10 says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government table in the Parliament the reports (detailed at Table 2.2 of this report) prepared by the various Commonwealth agencies in response to our obligations under UN human rights treaties.

We are a signatory to the United Nations human rights conventions and to a number of covenants—the civil and political covenant and the economic, social and cultural covenant. Every couple of years Australia is required to report to the United Nations on our achievement of those aims. We must report what we are doing as a country to ensure that our people get those rights.

PARA.TAB: However, this parliament, which is the democratic forum of the people of this nation, does not actually see those reports. There is no debate in parliament about what is in those reports. There is no debate about what our nation is telling the international community we are doing to fulfil our human rights obligations.

I believe it is important to ensure that the people of this nation and their parliamentary representatives have an opportunity to consider what the government has submitted and to debate that, so I strongly support that recommendation. I also strongly support recommendation No. 11, which says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee recommends that the Government reinstate the regular human rights reports from all Australian diplomatic posts and urges the Government to make provision in resources and training for officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade to carry out the task.

This is a very important initiative. Our government does not put together a report like that from our diplomatic posts around the world. Such a report would help us as parliamentarians. It would also help Australians to better understand what is happening around the world.

PARA.TAB: If we were able to pull together, on an annual or a two-yearly basis, a report about what is happening around the world, Australians travelling overseas would know what was happening in each country. They would know the human rights records of various countries, and they would have a better idea of whether they should be dealing with or visiting those countries. We may well then be able to avoid some of the tragedies that we have had in the past with Australian nationals losing their lives because of terrorist activities or abuses of human rights in other countries.

Such a report would ensure that all our government departments could be better informed in their dealings with other countries. They would have a clearer understanding of the human rights records in various countries. A number of countries, including the US, already prepare such a report on an annual basis. Those countries thus have a very important tool in the form of regular reports from their diplomatic posts. Australia should encourage that as well.

Recommendation No. 14 is another important recommendation. It suggests that this subcommittee should be converted into a full joint standing committee. Criticism is often heard in this place—and I believe it is justified—that there are too many committees in the parliament. We all suffer from the fact that we are on too many committees and so we do not have enough time to concentrate on the issues that we think are important.

However, human rights is an issue that this parliament should not ignore. In recommending a full joint committee on human rights, we are not adding to the number of committees but merely giving the current subcommittee the status of a full committee. The major impact of that would be to ensure that we have better resources to enable the committee to do its work. As has already been stated in this chamber this morning, Margaret Swieringa has virtually produced this report single handed. Apart from the very valuable assistance that she has had from one or two people from time to time, she has had to carry a huge workload. If it were a full joint standing committee, she would have three or four research staff to support her.

Nothing is more important to Australia's international standing than our obligations to observe human rights and to promote human rights around the world. We need to resource the committee more adequately so that we, as a parliament, can contribute to the promotion of human rights in a more forthright manner and so that our committee can do its work fully. I very strongly support the recommendation that the human rights subcommittee be converted to a full joint standing committee. We have already, as a subcommittee, discussed the ways in which we could ensure that that occurred with minimal disruption and so that there was still full cooperation between the human rights committee and the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade.

The only other comment I would like to make is in relation to comments that the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) made regarding East Timor. As the member for Throsby said, our recommendation is one of compromise, but it is a reasonable compromise. I would have gone a lot further. I am a person who has said consistently in this parliament that I disagree with successive Australian governments' position on East Timor. I do not believe we should have recognised the incorporation of East Timor into Indonesia. I believe it was an act of invasion and an act of violence against the rights of the people of East Timor. I believe that the Indonesians should leave East Timor and let East Timorese decide for themselves what their future should be.

But I think the recommendation in this report is an important first step. What should happen is that the Indonesians should reduce their military presence in that country significantly. They should give the East Timorese an opportunity to administer themselves and to decide for themselves their own future. I commend this report to the Main Committee and I hope the government will support all the recommendations.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hawker) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Barry Jones:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jones The Hon B.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before resuming my remarks on the tabling of the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies report on Australia's population carrying capacity, I seek leave to table some corrections to the report, together with an amended copy of the report. The changes are typographical, apart from the elimination of recommendation 10, which was inadvertently duplicated. Any reprint of the report should contain these alterations.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Committee. Of the 271 submissions received, over 90 per cent advocated population stability or lower population growth. Less than 10 per cent of submissions argued for an increase in population. On both sides extreme views were expressed. On the population reduction side, a few submissions argued that the present population should be encouraged to dwindle to as low as seven million, one million or until it equalled the estimated indigenous population of Australia before 1788. But the opposite and extreme figures of 80 or 100 million were cited as desirable possibilities.

PARA.TAB: While the overwhelming majority of submissions provided statements of opinion rather than analyses of the issues covered by the terms of reference, about 10 per cent of the total provided detailed analytical surveys of a range of economic, demographic, ecological or other issues related to Australia's population carrying capacity. Of these, 15 were from academics and scientists with an identified institutional affiliation, and others were from government departments, scientific professional associations, policy research associations and environmental organisations.

While most submissions simply nominated population targets within what was seen as a desirable range, and did not attempt to provide any analysis of the factors that must be considered in an evaluation of national carrying capacity, there was recognition on the part of scientific and academic contributors, including the CSIRO, that any analysis which took account of a sufficient range of relevant factors would necessarily be extremely complex. In order to obtain more evidence on the range of economic and scientific issues which provided insights into the question of Australia's carrying capacity, the committee examined 23 witnesses representative of a wide range of expertise and community opinion.

The committee concluded that Australia's politically and socially realistic population options may be confined to four which deserve serious, ongoing, well-informed community debate. The options are: first, relatively high population growth, with a figure by the middle of next century of between 30 and 50 million; second, a moderate population growth option resulting in a figure of between 23 and 30 million; third, a stabilisation option of a figure of between 17 to 23 million; and, four, a moderate reduction option which would see population reduced to between five and 17 million by mid next century.

The option with the strongest community support is clearly that of population stabilisation by the middle of the next century of around 23 million. This figure could readily be achieved by imposing a net migration target of 50,000 a year. However, the committee was not prepared to recommend a specific upper limit, recognising that public perceptions about acceptable levels change from time to time and should be the subject of ongoing community debate.
In chapter 3, `Challenging mythologies about population and quality of life', the committee identified and discussed 12 of the most familiar misconceptions about population.

The tables and maps in the report provide useful comparative data. As the tables on pages 29 and 31 indicate, Australia ranks ahead of the US in annual internal renewable water resources per capita, but is well behind Canada, and in annual freshwater withdrawals per capita it is behind the US and Canada but well ahead of Japan, Turkey, Vietnam and Indonesia.

As paragraph 2.25 points out, the soil-climate homologues for the 80 per cent of Australia classified as arid or semi-arid are, like much of Africa, incapable of sustainably supporting any form of agricultural production other than extensive pastoralism.

Paragraph 2.26 says that, conversely, the better-watered 20 per cent of the continent is capable of supporting agricultural crop and pasture systems analogous to those of western Europe and north America. That is not to say that the higher rainfall areas of Australia could support farming populations at the same density as western Europe or the mid-west of the United States.

The immediate reasons for this are that Australian soils were infertile by world standards and the Australian climate highly variable. While Australia has a very high level of arable land per capita by world standards, 2.8 hectares versus a world average of 0.33 hectares, the quality of Australian arable land is low and big population increases would soon reduce our quality corrected area of crop land per head towards the world average.

The quality of public debate on population matters is another important issue tackled in the committee's inquiry. Again, it is an issue which has arisen partly from the public confusion over the role of the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs in relation to population matters. Some submissions argued a lack of confidence in the objectivity and independence of research conducted by the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research with respect to the long-term effects of immigration, and on population research generally. Serious gaps in the material published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics on population matters were also identified. However, the quality of the ABT data is commended and its work is regarded as authoritative.

To make informed judgments on the range of matters relevant to population policy, it is necessary not only to conduct research into a range of environmental reporting and social trends data but to identify sources which provide such data and to ensure that it is readily accessible to the wider public. Information needs to be kept up to date for summaries of demographic data and relevant population projections available as a form of published annual or biennial reports.

It is clear from evidence to the committee that the perceived absence of independently produced, publicly available research data, including demographic projections, resource assessment and quality of life data, has directly inhibited the quality of public debate and has by default encouraged views expressing extremes of optimism and pessimism among participants.

It is essential to recognise that what may be `desirable' in terms of population size must not be confused with what is `feasible' or politically and socially achievable. In other words, population is a political issue and must be dealt with by political means, not by pretending that it is too difficult and ignoring it altogether. By making evidence available and by improving the quality and objectivity of population research, debate on the issue may concentrate on realistic and acceptable alternatives for a population policy.

Australia has, as the committee's report explains, always had a bipartisan approach to immigration policy, but there have been fluctuations in the community's tolerance of migrants at different times and intake levels have always varied according to current perceptions of Australia's requirements and obligations. Governments have always operated on the basis of a reasonable degree of community consensus, indicated by the degree of bipartisanship achieved. We should not abandon this approach. This view is reflected in the committee's conclusion that Australia would do well to adopt a precautionary position with regard to population policy in accordance with principles of ecologically sustainable development.

The committee was concerned about the rise of irrationalism in politics, some with a green tinge, especially the recent phenomenon which links concern for preserving the environment with a strongly racist, anti-migrant mood, something which has arisen in Britain, France, Germany, Italy and Australia. This tends to make migrants a scapegoat and raises a false or exaggerated dichotomy: there can be wilderness, unspoiled rivers and unpolluted beaches or migrants, but not both. It is a gross oversimplification. It also diverts attention away from where it ought to be: on proper resource management, improved waste disposal, energy efficiency, rethinking the real, social cost of water.

So we should oppose the rigidity that asserts that immigration is the only variable to worry about in considering environmental impact, leading to a fatalism that existing practices will go on unchanged and that technologies such as recycling, water conservation and energy efficiency will not improve the situation.

The committee was also sceptical about the argument of a direct correlation between population growth, loss of biodiversity and deforestation, that is, population growth in isolation. In 3.18 the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: As pointed out in the CSIRO submission to the Inquiry, the most ruthless devastation of Australian forests occurred in the 19th century when population increases were comparatively limited (i.e. when the population rose from 2 to 5 million). Biodiversity is a current term used to describe the variousness of life forms and the variety of ways in which that life is organised into ecosystems. Loss of biodiversity is a reference to the fact that many plant and animal species have become extinct in Australia since European settlement.
In 3.19, the report continues:

Loss of habitat—transformation of places where plants and animals live—is well recognised as the main cause of biodiversity loss. All land use intensification causes habitat loss, including urbanisation and the laying down of infrastructure. Land use intensification is strongly associated in peoples' perception with population growth. It is also strongly associated with the development of agriculture and forestry. For example, the loss of many mammal species in the rangelands has paralleled the spread of pastoralism, an activity supporting only sparse human population. The causal relationship between these two factors is complicated by associated factors such as the decline of Aboriginal `firestick farming.'
Feral animals have been the cause of biocide and their operation has little, if any, connection with population growth.

PARA.TAB: Chapter 5, `World population growth and Australian population policy', attempts to place the national situation in a context of the world population explosion, the subject of the Cairo conference. The extreme pressure of population in such countries as Bangladesh and much of Africa revives the spectre of the Reverend Thomas Malthus. His dire warnings, 200 years after publication, are starting to seem realistic in the Third World. Are they applicable to Australia as well? The committee was doubtful.

Nevertheless it is clear that population can no longer be regarded as a national issue only. Australia's policy response must be formulated in the global context of a worldwide population explosion. At Cairo, Australia gave explicit support to the principle that all nations have a responsibility to stabilise their populations as soon as possible, and accepted that we can continue to assist developing countries with non-coercive family planning programs, and through our refugee program.
The committee's recommendation No. 9 was:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Government continue to make it clear that Australia's contribution for assisting the problems of global overpopulation will be a combination of aid, expertise and example, pointing out that reduced fertility rates have a close relationship with encouraging education for girls and women and with rising levels of prosperity. In addition, Australia must improve its efforts to reduce the impact of global pollution, particularly the emission of greenhouse gases.

PARA.TAB: I want to thank the members of the committee, all those who prepared submissions and gave evidence and all those who worked so hard in contributing to the report, especially the committee's faithful, conscientious, expert, overworked and patient staff. The report is and should remain a valuable resource document in the ongoing debate about Australia's population.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a real pleasure to follow the chairman of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Long Term Strategies, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), in this tabling of the report Australia's population `carrying capacity': one nation—two ecologies. One of the great criticisms of politicians of this country is that we look only from election to election, so it was a delight to participate in this inquiry and enjoy the many opportunities provided as we looked out over the horizon a little and contemplated what the population of the country might be. In his press club speech the member for Lalor referred to Griffith Taylor and the fact that he got it pretty right in 1922. Let us hope that our report is as accurate 70 years hence and that we have done our nation a service.

PARA.TAB: Of course, governments have the responsibility to monitor and plan for our population. The system at the moment is too ad hoc. We cannot continue to rely on luck and chance, chopping and changing our policy every year. We need a long-term view, particularly if we are to wisely use our natural resources and maintain our liberal democratic processes. The committee found that the most likely optimum population for Australia is 23 million. We have said that immigration policy is different from population policy, and our chairman has noted the irrationality which has come into our political debate from time to time.

Presently, our population clings to the coasts of Australia and our cities. We have an urban and regional culture, and it was noted that many of the submissions had that green tinge. I suppose it was a pleasure to work in the committee and find that all the submissions were respected for the effort that had gone into them but at the same time we stayed within a fairly strict framework of objectivity and professionalism.

The chairman noted that the main environmental damage to this country was done in the last century, and that is something that should be highlighted in this report. Those people who may care to study the report in depth will note that chapter 1, `History of population and population debate in Australia' is very comprehensive. For someone like me who is relatively new in the parliament it has been a wonderful opportunity to look at our past because it is only by looking at our past, as we all know, that we understand where we are at now and develop a better future.

In chapter 2 the committee considers the continental `carrying capacity' of Australia. `Stocking capacity' was, as the chairman acknowledged from time to time, a little crude, but that is what we were trying to come to terms with. In that comparative assessment we have gone to some lengths to look at environmental issues and international comparisons. For example, we have touched on the Murray-Darling Basin, a quite critical part of our Australian environmental and economic situation.

The committee considered everything from the rangelands to the high rainfall zones and land degradation, which has assumed a prominence in political debate over the last decade or so. Salinisation, acidification, weeds and feral animals are all dealt with as part of the impact on land degradation. We look at the prospects for Australian agriculture and acknowledge that the long-term future of Australia as a food supplier is quite important internationally and very important nationally.

Chapter 3, where we deal with challenging mythologies about population and quality of life, gets into a little bit more subjectivity and is perhaps a little closer to some of the political debates that the chair has referred to and that vary from time to time. Nevertheless, it deals with the subject with the objectivity and professionalism which I believe serves the parliament well and will serve the country well. It does lay down quite clearly the basis of our considerations.

Chapter 4 is entitled `The role of information in the population debate'. There is an unlimitable and unlimited amount of data available on this subject but this chapter tries very hard to come to terms with relevant data from international sources and from within our own country, and looks at the research questions in all of these debates. Research is very important in that it gives us the opportunity to look out over the horizon.

The next chapter is about world population growth and Australian population policy. Australia presents the great advantage that, living under a stable democratic institution, we have the luxury of being able to consider these things with professional support and it is open to every member of the Australian community to be able to consider this. When we look at what happens in the international community, we become more aware of the privilege of living in this country. It is a little ironical to me that we—particularly the non-Aboriginal component of our population—with a chequered past in terms of understanding our environment as we settled this country, coming to terms with our mistakes and learning to deal with the issues on a day-by-day basis, still have the opportunity in this report to understand that and look to the future with great confidence and optimism. That is part of the ongoing institution—I suppose I seem to be labouring the point—which I am proud to be part of as part of my heritage.

The chair has covered what the submissions said about population size. It was quite valuable for me, in the open, formal component of the inquiry, that those people had the opportunity to come forward and present their opinions direct to the committee and that I could listen and ask questions about which direction we might take. I remember particularly the one million population option, which highlighted to me the great diversity of opinion that is out there in our community. The chapter on options for population policy has been well covered by the chair. A great effort was made to try to understand what the future consumption and population policy would be from the perspective of the Aboriginals, the original settlers of our continent.

I return to my roots, I suppose, in noting that Australia's agricultural production and exports have doubled, while the area of land farmed has gone up by 16 per cent, with fewer people working those bigger farms. That is an example, if ever there was one, of the movement of population out of rural Australia and into the regional cities and into the cities of Australia. One witness in particular said that cities have a great capacity to regenerate; they are the preferred place of living for the overwhelming majority of Australians.

Despite some of the mythology surrounding regional Australia, this highlights the great variation over 100 years, where we do not know what is ahead of us. Fifty years ago, say, there were comparatively a lot of people out in regional Australia. Although so many of them have come into cities, even through the changes—the technology and all the rest of it—population growth has occurred quite safely and the quality of life has been protected. That highlights the moves and changes which our environment can accommodate with intelligence and the technological advances that are available to us.

In the remaining three or four minutes that I have, I wish to touch on what we might look for from the youth of this nation. As I have stated at least twice, this report lays down professionally and in a bipartisan way the population capacity of our country. It is not being too prescriptive: it is being realistic and practical in the way it has dealt with the various components of the debate. Australia is a world leader in its democratic institutions and in its intellectual property and the way we make our decisions, which gives us every confidence of being a strong democracy into the 21st century.

To those young people who will be looking back on this report and making some judgment on us—as I have had the good fortune to do, through the good offices of our chairman, on Griffith Taylor, who, in 1922, estimated that the population would be 20 million about now—I would say that a doomsday philosophy has been about for too long. We have every reason, based on reports such as this, to be confident and optimistic. I do not say, nor do I think any member of the committee would, that this report is the be-all and end-all of the debate. I suggest that the chairman would agree with me that it is but a good basis for the beginning of the debate.

I would ask the young people of Australia that we be judged in the fullness of time—over the next 30 or 40 years—to see how close we have got. I have every confidence that our report will not have been exactly accurate, but I have equal confidence that it is an excellent base to build on with confidence and optimism—because I have that sort of confidence in my country and its people. With those few words—and with grateful acknowledgment of our staff, who with great diligence, patience and effort have given the committee wonderful support, and with whom it has been a pleasure to work, along with other members of the committee—I hope that those who read the report will gain from it what they would like to gain, and that it will serve the country well into the future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snow Mr J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The breadth of optimism contained in the speech of the chairman of the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones), and in the words of the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin) is very welcome in this parliament, particularly on this subject. In congratulating members of the committee, I would particularly mention the chairman, who is a great academic and a great political leader, and who has had a great career in administration in this parliament as a minister. He is someone who has the capacity to assimilate information from a wide range of fields in science and technology. For that reason, he has been of great benefit. I believe that many of the reports from this committee will be important reports in Australia's history, and I congratulate him on that. I also commend my colleagues on the committee for their involvement.

PARA.TAB: I mention the staff too. An inquiry like this has not been all that easy for the staff, and they have fed into the committee and performed really well. I did not mention that the chair can be pretty exacting, and I believe the staff did respond to the pressures that must come from the chair as he seeks to have a near perfect report. Even now he is finding items that he can correct in the report, I noticed. But we have come up with a very good report.

I will look at recommendation 15 for a start. It is recommended that Australia should commission a comprehensive cost-benefit analysis of developing technologies which reduce environmental impacts, for example, soil and water conservation technologies and capital intensive agricultural technologies such as greenhouse and hydroponic production. Australia has always had, as you would know, Mr Deputy Speaker, from your own electorate, a great advantage in climate over other countries of the world in our production.

This struck me when I was in Sweden about two months after the Chernobyl disaster. As we were going through Sweden in the middle of the summer, with beautiful, lush pasture, there were no animals to be seen. When I asked where all the animals were, I was told they were all locked up in their winter sheds. It was very convenient for Sweden after Chernobyl that people could lock all their livestock up. We would not be able to do that in Australia. With our hundreds of millions of sheep and other livestock, we just would not be able to do it. It did impress me then that in the winter some people have to accommodate their animals to an extent that we do not here. I asked myself whether Sweden and other countries will catch up with Australia with some of the developments in agricultural technologies on concentrated production—fish farming, for instance, and hydroponic production. Even here I think our climate is still an advantage, because with our temperature ranges we will have fewer energy costs.

I go to recommendation 14, where we recommend that the Australian government should encourage state and local governments, as a matter of high priority, to encourage development of sewerage and waste disposal systems that reduce the use of pristine water and/or environmentally sensitive land areas, and promote recycling. People have been coming to me and probably to other honourable members for some time now saying, `Why do we not do something with our sewage and our waste from cities like Melbourne, Sydney, Canberra, Adelaide, Perth, Darwin, Brisbane and Hobart?' Just recently a more feasible program, called liquid trees, has actually been developed in my own region. It draws on some of the technologies which are already available, including the transport of coal over quite long distances. Apparently coal can be transferred through pipes with the use of not a lot of energy, and it has been suggested that there are ways, under the liquid trees proposal, of making better use of the water involved with our sewage and waste disposal and diverting that water inland. It is the best such proposal I have seen so far.

As members, we are asked time and again why we cannot do what seems to people to be the obvious, and it is easy to respond, `This is just like turning the rivers backwards and that sort of thing, and the Snowy Mountains scheme could never happen again in Australia because of environmental pressures.' It is easy to respond like that, but we ought to look carefully at some of the proposals that come to us.

I want to comment on a few of the recommendations. I particularly emphasise recommendation 1, that the government should determine that population policy and immigration policy are quite distinct, with different goals. That is very important. As I see it, we should regard immigration as an instrument of population growth, and we have not been doing that. We have been making ad hoc decisions. There is pressure from the public and we make decisions almost annually on what our immigration level should be. The point made by the report is that immigration and population growth should be regarded as distinct. Recommendation 7(b) of the report says:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bureau of Immigration and Population Research be renamed as the Bureau of Population Research and transferred to the Department of Prime Minister and Cabinet to service the proposed Cabinet Committee on Population.

It is suggested that a cabinet committee on population be formed with its own research budget of at least $1 million annually to fund scientific research programs to enable more informed, evidence based analysis of population policy options. We say in recommendation 12:

While emphasising that immigration policy is only one aspect of a national population policy, proponents of radical change to existing policy and practice in immigration intake should bear the burden of proof.

I believe that is very important. We have maintained the status of immigration as it was in 1961, when about 16 per cent of people were prepared to say outright that immigration should be reduced. We are sticking to that sort of status here in the parliament, and we have consideration of immigration almost equal to our consideration of what we are doing about our population—whether we ought to have growth or otherwise.

PARA.TAB: It is important to mention that the report highlights the proper place of immigration: as an instrument, not as an end in itself. It has been shown quite clearly in the report that, while there may be an effect from immigration on the cost of living, it could be marginally beneficial. There may also be an effect on the environment, but the effect is not nearly as great as both the proponents and opponents of increased immigration claim.

Another recommendation that ought to be mentioned is recommendation 10, which suggests that we ought to be asking what the incremental effects downstream are. That is very important. The recommendation says:

SPEECH.PARA: The Australian Government should develop a population policy which explicitly sets out a range of options for long term population change, emphasising that year by year decisions on immigration intake cannot be taken in an ad hoc fashion.

In recommendation 11 we look at something quite different: a consumption strategy. The report recommends that we adopt a consumption strategy such that we think about the benefits of modifying our behaviour and use of products—modifying our behaviour in the purchase of products and in the disposal of products as well. It is important that we develop a consumption strategy, because if we do that nationally then it is going to permeate our education system. We have shown on environmental issues and on racial tolerance issues that we as parliaments around Australia are not bad at influencing the education system. Schoolteachers quite often take up the lead that thinking people in the parliament can provide to them. As the recommendation here in the report says:

Australia should adopt a consumption strategy, to be developed around the challenge of learning to move from high levels of consumption based on high levels of material throughput per unit of consumption to lower levels of consumption based on lower levels of material throughput per unit of consumption. Such a strategy need not reduce quality of life—
an important point to note—
although it may change the way in which people enjoy quality lives.

The report also looks at some of the myths involved—and I must admit that I was guilty of believing some of them myself. As myths often can, these do have a degree of truth in some cases. For instance, one is that Australia has one of the world's most serious shortages of water. We actually have the water; the real problem is the price of getting it places. We show in paragraph 3.2 that Australia is one of the better endowed countries in the world for water, but the water is not in areas where people live. About two-thirds of all the run-off is in the northern fifth of the country, where it is difficult to store water cheaply because of the lack of good dam sites and the high variability of rainfall. It is not clear whether Australians would want to pay the price of getting a lot more water to places where it is needed to cope with population change.

PARA.TAB: Another myth is that Australia is just a big desert, unsuitable for human settlement. It seems pretty evident that it is true that high density subsistence populations are not an option for most of the rangelands in Australia. We looked at the issue of environmental degradation—for example, salinity and blue-green algae in the Murray-Darling Basin—and whether it is due to the population size and the rate of growth. It seems, and it is shown in our report, that the problem of blue-green algae outbreaks in the Murray-Darling river system is partly due to increasing inputs of phosphates in the sewerage system as the population in the Murray-Darling Basin rises. It is also partly due to the use of phosphate fertilisers at levels recommended more by technology choice than by the population in the basin. The CSIRO gave us evidence in relation to that.

There is also a view that loss of biodiversity and the deforestation are directly related to the size of the population and its rate of growth. I can recall reading something of the words of Strzelecki—or, as the Poles pronounce it, `Streletzki'—when he visited the Kosciusko area or, as the Poles pronounce it, `Kozchusko'. When he saw the Monaro frost plains, which did not have many trees, he said that there could well be problems with hoofed animals and with the axe where there were trees—in other words, the removing of trees from the few places where there were trees. The word `Monaro' comes from the Aboriginal word `maneroo', which means `maidens' breasts': the plains were undulating hills. The early explorers wrote back to London and Sydney and said, `Here is good clean country,' which meant they did not have to chop down a whole lot of trees. Sure enough, the hoofed animals came and did quite a lot of damage.

We are concerned about the actions of people. If we could think about productivity and sustainability more than population, we would be targeting the problem a bit better. Naturally none of us can cover all of the report but, once again, I pay compliments to the chair, to the staff and to my fellow committee members. I am very proud of our report entitled Australia's population `carrying capacity': one nation—two ecologies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to be part of this debate to take note of our report entitled Australia's population `carrying capacity': one nation—two ecologies. As did other members of the committee, I acknowledge the driving force not only behind this report but also behind the House of Representatives Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies, the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones). It was his intense interest in this area that encouraged the rest of the committee to decide on this inquiry and it has been a most interesting inquiry. As other speakers have said, we are often, as politicians, related to the day and the moment, but it is very important that we spend more time on the longer-term issues.

PARA.TAB: It is interesting that two different reports in Tuesday's Australian, written in response to the tabling of our report, indicate the range of the debate. Richard Blandy's article in the `Opinion' section is headed `Why an ageing Australia needs to support bigger families'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: A large population problem is looming for Australia in the next century. Unless Australian women have more babies or the number of immigrants arriving in Australia each year becomes larger our population will start to shrink.

Professor Blandy is no amateur: he is Professor Richard Blandy of the Institute of Applied Economic and Social Research at the University of Melbourne. He goes on to discuss options, and one he is looking at is more effective economic measures to encourage women to have more children.

PARA.TAB: The other article is by Tom Dusevic. Titled `The number's up', it looks at an alternative viewpoint in terms of whether we really have a population crisis. Varying opinions were put to the committee during the course of its inquiry. I refer also to Geoffrey McNicoll from the ANU Research School of Social Sciences and a paper he presented to the Australian Population Association in Canberra in September this year. That paper is also quoted in our report. As he indicates, `demography has been a major issue in Australia's development since European settlement'. Initially, we had the sorts of fertility rates that one sees with frontier societies. However, this began to change in the latter part of the 19th century, and in fact so concerned was Australia that it set up a royal commission in 1903. This commission deplored the evident resort to contraception and held the underlying cause to be—and he quotes the actual report of the 1904 royal commission:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . "selfishness"—people placing their personal well-being ahead of the task of peopling the continent.
However, despite the concerns of the royal commission fertility continued to decline, reaching replacement level in the 1930s. As McNicoll notes:

The transition to low fertility has coincided with industrialization, urbanization and the emergence of the consumer economy, with expansion of education and paid employment for women, and with large changes in marriage and family arrangements and in people's expectations about them. In various combinations these produce irresistible downward pressure on births. The Royal Commissioners if alive today would be dismayed at the scale of selfishness revealed.

The issue here is that all attempts by governments to encourage women to have more babies to increase the population of the country are likely to fail. In fact, with the advent of contraception, women have voted with their feet and have found that in spite of the delights of procreation and child raising there are numerous delights in the wider world that will ultimately discourage all attempts to have women produce seven children, as was the case earlier in our history.

PARA.TAB: The article in the Australian by Dusevic is very interesting because it quotes one of the issues that we considered in our report, one that was referred to us by Katharine Betts from the Swinburne Institute of Technology when she said:

SPEECH.PARA: Finding an optimum population involves value judgments. Different population sizes maximise different goals. For example, a smaller number would commit Australians to continue to aspire to a detached house and a garden. Larger numbers might permit each State to have a world-class opera company. This is a question of people's values and preferences, and that really means that it is a political question.

Over and above that and in opposition to that view, several submissions concerned the environmental issues that we must face. Quoting further from the Australian article, the CSIRO argued that as things stand:

Australia lacks the necessary knowledge and understanding to manage effectively its current population at current living standards. Every extra person, and every unit increase in consumption, increases the need to rectify this situation.
However, I just want to quote again from a CSIRO submission to our committee, on page 95, from Dr Howard Dengate. It states:

The human impact on the environment is a function not only of population, but also of lifestyle, organisation and technology . . . Any rise in population will increase the necessity and urgency to do what already needs to be done to enhance Australia's population `carrying capacity'. Resource and infrastructure issues, especially regarding water and energy use and waste disposal, already require more attention if Australia is to achieve an ecologically sustainable way of life. If these issues are not adequately addressed, Australia can expect further degradation of land and water resources in certain regions of the coastal zone and on inland river systems, compromising its quality of life—even at current population levels.

Many of the people who attended our public inquiries and submitted to the committee put an argument that, given the ecological consequences of population pressure on our continent, we should limit our population. But I believe it is vitally important that we look at population in terms of the policy mix, particularly in terms of how we manage the impact of our current population and increases in our population.

PARA.TAB: Therefore, it is very clear that we have to balance those issues and, rather than go back to a golden past where very few people impacted on the environment, we have to look realistically at the current impact and future impacts in terms of our resource use. This is one of the issues that Australia has simply got to stop walking away from as being too hard. It is an area that local, state and federal governments must address in an integrated way if we are going to be able to sustain our current population and, indeed, cope with an increase in population.

I think one of the earlier concerns, the populate or perish myth, which was presented to us again in different forms, relates to our role in Asia. It is becoming clearer that we will not need a massive increase in population simply to sustain ourselves, because government policy is about moving as an integrated partner into the Asia-Pacific region. We will be able to sustain our current standard of living and, indeed, increase our standard of living, if we are effective as an exporter of manufactured goods and services to the Asia-Pacific area. That in itself will have environmental consequences that we will have to be very aware of.

I want to refer again to McNicoll's article, because he does look at the lack of population policy. Indeed, this was highlighted in submissions to our report on page 119 where we quoted from Australia's official submission to the 1994 Cairo conference on population and development. That submission stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . Australia does not have an explicit or formal population policy directly aimed at influencing the level of population . . . the Government decided that a formal population policy (particularly one which would specify population targets) would not be appropriate for Australia, given its low levels of fertility and diversity of community views as to the character and objectives of such a policy.

It is the view of the committee that this kind of flicking of population policy into a too-hard basket is not going to be a very effective way to handle this very important question in the future. On page 118 the report quotes from the McNicoll paper that I have referred to before:

Public policy making is a kind of moveable feast. Sets of issues become conjoined, seen by government as requiring coordinated attention, while other `neighbouring issues' are conceptually detached, seen as allied elsewhere or left wholly aside . . . Components of what could potentially be an Australian population policy are instead decided on in other policy arenas. They are not plausibly to be shaken loose in some overall reconfiguration of the make-up of public policy.
Further in his paper, and it certainly supports our recommendations, McNicoll says this:

The approaching centenary of federation is seen as the occasion for a systematic assessment of the institutions of the state, the outcome seen as ranging variously between confident celebration of the original vision and radical renovation . . . Absurdly, however, we choose to relegate population to being a byproduct of all our other decisions. Our stance toward this fundamental dimension of our future is a bizarre helplessness.
I think that certainly supports the view in our recommendations which I want to refer to in the time left. In our principles, 8.1, we said:

So far, much of the debate about population and the `carrying capacity' of the Continent has been of poor quality, highly emotive, with extremes of optimism and pessimism, not based on a rigorous consideration of evidence—for example, about rates of per capita resource use, availability of water, etc.
The chair of the committee was quoted in the Australian of 6 December. The newspaper said:

It was important for governments to understand that population and immigration were not synonymous, it said, arguing that setting a population policy was a "primary goal" and that choosing immigration levels was a secondary consequence.
I quote further:
Immigration intake must be an instrument of population policy, population policy cannot be a long-term unconsidered side effect of ad hoc immigration practice.
I think what we have said in recommendation No. 1 cannot be quoted too often. The recommendation said:

The Government should determine that population policy and immigration policy are quite distinct, with differing goals, although the long term consequences are inextricably linked. The political and administrative responsibility for population and immigration must be separated.

I think our report is a very important contribution to the debate. I hope that McNicholl is wrong when he suggests that it may have no more effect than previous reports in this country. I think it is a very important issue. The government must put consideration into it. It must be coordinated and I believe that we should not allow it to be highjacked by extremists, particularly some of those presenters to our committee who very much took a racist and an ethnocentric view of this issue.

PARA.TAB: We Australians who have enjoyed the delights of living in a sparsely populated country really have to be accountable now for the way we have used and abused this precious environmental resource as we head towards the centenary of Federation. This is a very important issue and I hope the government will take our recommendations seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —The latest report of the Standing Committee for Long Term Strategies, Australia's population `carrying capacity': one nation—two ecologies, shows the findings of the committee in relation to the terms of reference for an inquiry into Australia's population carrying capacity. The committee was to consider what sort of population level Australia could support in 50 years and whether we should actually be setting a population target. Tied with the question of population was the question of how population change affects the environmental, economic and social development of our nation.

PARA.TAB: I think the committee's decision to put population growth and immigration in different categories was a good one. Although they are linked, there are very different policy requirements for the management of long-term population change and immigration policy. From the submissions I gleaned a lot of information. There really were quite diverse views, going from a decrease of the population to a level before European settlement to anything in excess of 100 million. There were some quite subjective arguments to go along with both extremes.

However, the committee's view was to equate population carrying capacity with a best, or optimum, population rather than a maximum population. The sorts of concepts for looking at carrying capacity brought out things like the availability of food, water and waste disposal, or an ability to recycle. It is these sorts of things that give us the quality of life. At a cities conference held recently in Melbourne, the theme that seemed to intrigue our overseas neighbours, and even the participants from Europe, was Australia's strong desire to keep a quality of life higher than most—even, it seemed, at some cost, such as full employment or equity issues.

Quality of life also came out in the many arguments that were put forward by people submitting their thoughts to the committee. Quality of life is great, but sometimes the arguments that are used, such as `What is quality of life?' and `Whose life is of quality?', can be a little one-sided. Many of the people herded into our cities from the country areas because of rural job decline and changes in technology may feel that their quality of life has been eroded. Many who have lost their jobs through changing work patterns and industry restructuring may feel their quality of life has been taken away. Perhaps an increase of population in certain areas might assist those who feel that their quality of life has been challenged.

At present, Australia has no population policy which sets out broad goals for the long term. We have the immigration targets which reflect economic factors, such as unemployment or economic growth rates, and which have long-term population implications. But we need a policy to look at where we are going and/or where we want to go, rather than a lot of improvising. The committee has come up with a concept in which, physically, Australia may be conceived of as two highly habitable segments or islands, separated by an enormous sea of arid and semi-arid landscapes, of mainly salty and sandy soils, which occupy some 70 per cent of the continent—or 7.7 million square kilometres. The two islands were defined as the south-west corner of Western Australia and the Cairns to Adelaide seaboard, and Tasmania was seen as a third island. The carrying capacity of the arid bits is obviously not going to make that area one which supports many people. So around 10 per cent of Australia is where 95 per cent of Australians live.

The committee has therefore given the report the subtitle `one nation—two ecologies' and I believe this gives a good visual idea as to where our decision making needs to be directed. There is also a new formula, devised by the CSIRO, which is a valuable conceptual tool. It looks at the importance of the organisation of space and of technology, as well as population and lifestyle, as determining factors in the quality and form of human settlement. The example used is the Netherlands. It has a far higher density than Haiti, but its quality of life is superior because of better organisation of resource use, including waste management. This formula could be used for a number of extensions to its original development when we are, say, looking at regional development or city planning.

Tasmania has always been a bit of Australia that gets forgotten about. It is left off the map occasionally and is seen as rather irrelevant in planning, in overall Australian terms.
