I am not saying that with any malice; it is just the way life is. I believe it is because we have such a low population base and we have no strength in numbers. Because we are an island, in all the senses of the word, we have the potential for being a model or a pilot for any work that needs testing before being let loose on the rest of Australia. This has recently been recognised and a number of programs are looking at information exchange and some health issues. But I could see this as being useful as a pilot for an increase in population. We can certainly sustain a lot more, but we will have to become smarter and more efficient in our use of resources, particularly water and energy, and also our primary resources, such as wood and minerals. However, to be smarter, we need more skills and more people.

I agree with the committee's concern about the rise of irrationalism in politics, especially within the green movement. Some members of the green movement seem to be linking the concern for preserving the environment with a strongly racist and anti-immigration movement which has also arisen in Europe. This trend to make migrants the scapegoats raises a false division. For example, the argument is that we can have wilderness, unspoiled rivers and unpolluted beaches or we can have migrants, but we cannot have both. It is a stupid argument and it should be rejected.

They say that about employment as well. That argument is simplistic. It also diverts attention from proper resource management through improved waste disposal, energy efficiency and controlling water costs. There are even arguments about population growth leading to a loss of biodiversity and deforestation. We should be very wary of some of these arguments as they are not based on sustainable facts.

There are no definable limits. The committee believes that population should be seen as over immigration, with the greater emphasis on long-term consequences. We need an ongoing debate based on high quality information and independent research. We must look at what is feasible and what is desirable. We must also allay exaggerated fears of what overpopulation might do—but not let it dictate the agenda.

It has been a pleasure to have been a part of putting this report together. My compliments go to my fellow committee members and, of course, to the honourable member for Lalor (Mr Barry Jones) for his guidance. Working on this committee has involved a great deal of information gathering and it has been a very stimulating committee to be on. I recommend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Hicks) adjourned.
Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Mr Peter Morris:
That the House take note of the report.

Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—I understand that it is the wish of the Main Committee to enable members, in referring to the motion to take note of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure report on communications and transport infrastructure requirements of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, to also refer to the progress report on monitoring of issues in the report of the inquiry into ship safety and the report on the review of the Auditor-General's audit report on the national highway. There being no objection, I will allow that course to be followed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Morris The Hon P.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Far be it from me to create any confusion, but my understanding was that we would not be speaking until about 12.30 p.m. My deputy chairman has just arrived. I understood that he was going to be the first speaker. Be that as it may, what I would like to do, if it meets the wishes of the chairman, is to commence the discussion, but I may like to make further comments after the other speakers if I have not had a chance to address all the issues.

PARA.TAB: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Andrew)—As the member for Shortland would understand, given his experience in this place, I am happy to allow whatever meets the wishes of the Committee. Frankly, with leave of the Committee, you can continue your remarks later if you choose so to do.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you very much for your wise advice. During the presentation of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure report on communications and transport infrastructure requirements of the Sydney 2000 Olympic Games, progress report on monitoring of issues in the report of the inquiry into ship safety and report on the review of the Auditor-General's audit report on the national highway reports in the main chamber of the House of Representatives there was clearly inadequate time to speak to the reports, and I want to make that point very strongly here. The 45 minutes that was allowed for the tabling of all of the reports and statements last Monday was utterly inadequate. It did not do justice to any of the subcommittees that were involved.

PARA.TAB: There was ample time later in the day for other reports to be discussed and tabled. If one had been watching the House during the afternoon one would have noticed that some members had difficulty in fleshing out the time that was available for those. I believe committee reports are extremely important. I value very much the work of our standing committees in the parliament and the work that colleagues on both sides of the House put into those inquiries and reports.

On behalf of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure I tabled three reports last Monday. The first was entitled Inquiry into the Sydney 2000 Olympics—the adequacy of existing and planned aviation services and infrastructure. The second was entitled Review inquiry into ship standards and safety. The third was Efficiency audit review: The national highway `Lifeline of the nation'.

Time did not permit me to speak to this last report and I would like to begin with a reference to that now. The Australian National Audit Office's review of the management of the national highway system was referred to the committee in December 1993. The review was carried out during times of change as the heads of government meeting in 1991 changed the road funding and management responsibilities of the Commonwealth and state governments.

As of 1 January 1994, the Commonwealth government assumed sole responsibility for the funding and management of the national highway, although the states will retain ownership of the roads. The Commonwealth will no longer fund any other types of roads. Most of the report's 33 recommendations have been accepted by the Department of Transport and in its response to the audit report the Department of Transport identified only five areas of disagreement.

Given the nature of the audit office's report, we decided as a committee that we would conduct a joint hearing at which both the Department of Transport and the Australian National Audit Office would participate. As a result of that meeting we found that the five areas of disagreement that had been identified by the Department of Transport were no longer a problem.

I might say from the committee's point of view that we found it a very useful exercise to have both the Department of Transport and the Australian National Audit Office present at the one time. To be able to address questions to either party or to both, even the same question to both, was very useful. We found that a very healthy inquiry procedure. It enabled matters to be resolved immediately where there was a contentious point. If the Department of Transport took a particular point of view and that had not been accepted earlier by the audit office, we would then turn immediately to the Australian National Audit Office.

My colleague the honourable member for Lyons (Mr Adams) is here with me and I think he would share the view that it was a very effective process. We had not done it before as a committee and we recommend that procedure to other inquiries. It makes a better use of time. It also makes the inquiry procedure much more effective, that we can test one view against the other there and then and not have to come back some time later. The committee believes that the changes made to the management of the national highway system are beneficial, particularly the introduction of performance agreements and performance indicators which will allow for improved, long-term planning of the national highway system.

I would like to thank the committee members for their assistance in completing the reports. We are particularly fortunate with this committee that we have members, from both sides of the House, who put a lot of effort into inquiries and investigations. We have a very supportive deputy chairman on the committee and to me, as a believer in the committee system, that is critical to the performance of the work of the committees.

There are so many things that we as a parliament can do through the committee system if the committee system is used effectively. But it has to be built upon a basis of cooperation between both sides of the House and participation by members of the committee. I think we are very fortunate in our committee in having that kind of basis.

Also, on behalf of the committee I want to thank the staff of the secretariat—Malcolm Aldons, Les Dunn and June Murphy—for their efforts and for responding to the call of duty at all sorts of unseemly hours when the pressure was on to get reports out and to get the work done. I would like also to offer special thanks to Denis James from the Parliamentary Library for his assistance on the Sydney 2000 Olympics report.I commend that report and the two other reports to the Committee today, as I sought to do in the House last Monday.

I return to the report that we tabled in respect of ship standards and safety. I want to emphasise to the Committee that this report is not a second Ships of shame report in terms of its depth, coverage and impact. It is a progress report. When we tabled the original Ships of shame report in December 1992, it had an impact right across the world. As a committee, we are very proud of that. As Australians, we are very proud of that. It has become a major handbook in many shipping companies right across the world and has had widespread support from all the maritime nations across the world. It has played an influential part in helping improve the standard of ship safety.

What we tabled on Monday was simply a review of what has happened to the recommendations of that report since December 1992 and what has been the response of our own government. I recommend that members of House peruse the latest report. We go through each recommendation of Ships of shame, setting out the response of our own government, and we briefly report on what is happening in other areas relevant to that inquiry. We must remember that in Australian ports we see only the best of the world's bulk iron ore and coal tankers. In terms of quality, the top 20 per cent of the world's ships utilise Australian ports.

Representatives of major exporters and loading facilities stated in evidence to the inquiry that they preferred to see quality shipping in the trades. That is a point that was raised very early in our original inquiry. If Australia was to be seen to be going it alone, in carrying out its responsibilities under the international maritime conventions which it has ratified, that would impact upon freight rates out of Australia and upon the cost of Australian exports and imports.

We had no evidence before us that this was the case. None at all. I intend to quote the evidence of some of the witnesses who came before us. It puts paid to the claim that if we insist on quality in shipping ships will not come to Australia. The evidence that I will read, from the transcript of the hearings of 27 May 1994, makes it very clear that, as far as the major shippers and ship operators in this country are concerned, what the market wants is quality.

On 27 May we had before us Mr George Benz, who is the General Manager of Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd. Mr Benz is responsible for the arrangement of shipping. In the case of Hamersley Iron, about 20 per cent of Hamersley iron ore sales are on a cost insurance freight basis, which means that the seller, Hamersley Iron, is responsible for arranging the shipping. It sells the product into the port of destination. The price includes the product, the cost of freight and the insurance. By that means, Hamersley Iron has complete control and responsibility for the product and costs until the product is unloaded at its port of destination.

Hamersley charters ships for that purpose. One remembers the loss of four bulk iron ore carriers that were loaded at Hamersley Iron's Dampier facility in 1990-91; those were ships that Hamersley had selected and their cargoes were all CIF sales of iron ore. Hamersley now has its own vetting system for the selection of ships and it took a very strong view in what it put to us in regard to making sure that the vessels do meet standards. Mr Benz told us:

SPEECH.PARA: I do feel that the charterer does have obligations to ensure the ship he uses is of good standard. I also feel that the charterers as a group do exercise that obligation. As you have pointed out in your initial report, Mr Chairman—
that reference is to my role at the inquiry—
it is a minority of participants who are the bad apples, who are the people who are most responsible for marine casualties.

We were putting to witnesses in Sydney, on 27 May 1994, the notion that charterers should bear responsibility. After all, it does not matter if the ship is substandard. It does not matter if a ship is unseaworthy. It is tied up at a buoy; it might leak a bit of oil, but it is not going to be much harm to anybody or anything. It is not until a charterer or a cargo owner comes along and says, `Yes I will use your vessel because you have got the cheapest rate, or I can get a benefit from it' that the harm arises.

PARA.TAB: So we put that view and questioned witnesses consistently: `Doesn't the charterer have a responsibility?' I hold the very strong personal view that the charterer does have a responsibility to ensure that the vessel is safe and seaworthy and meets the standards. We asked, `Does not the cargo owner have a responsibility?' and that gets a bit greyer, but I still hold that very strong view, because it is a cargo owner who is the beneficiary of cheap rates. It is the cargo owner who turns the key that sets that vessel in motion—with all of its dangers and risks to its crew and to the environment in which it operates. I said to Mr Benz:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if that ship has been hired on a repeated basis from time to time and the charterer or the hirer could have been reasonably expected to be aware of the condition of that vehicle—
or that vessel—
a similar kind of thing applies, does it not? It is public accountability, not legal responsibility.
Mr Benz's response was:
What I am driving at is, if a procurer of a service procures a service, knowing that it will lead to a casualty or constitute a danger, this is a conspiracy.

It is not Peter Morris saying that. It is not some rabid unionist saying that. The gentleman saying that is responsible for the arranging of the ships for the carriage of the product of one of the largest iron ore shipping companies in this nation. That was Mr Benz, on page 130 of the committee transcript.

PARA.TAB: We then talked more with Mr Benz as we went further along in his evidence. We were testing during the course of those hearings whether exporters and importers are prepared to pay for quality, or whether they want to avoid quality just to get the lowest possible rate. We had the same kind of evidence as came forward in support of quality in shipping from Mr Benz, on behalf of Hamersley Iron Pty Ltd; from Mr Clarebrough, on behalf of BHP Transport; and from Mr Anton Ugland, who was the immediate past president of Intertanko, the largest world association of independent tanker owners. We had a similar set of responses—all supporting quality in shipping—from Intercargo, the largest organisation in the world of bulk carrier owners and operators. Mr Benz told us, in reference to quality of shipping, at page 143 of the transcript:

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the shipping industry or any other industry is concerned, I think there is a growing realisation that quality pays. It is certainly gaining currency in Australia. It has already proved its worth in Japan, in particular. I think there is also evidence of a drift of so-called substandard ships away from the Pacific Basin, so that the users of ships in this part of the world now demand quality. The major charterers, the major parties dependent on sea transportation, now demand quality. A lot of ships which do not find employment here in the Pacific have been drifting into the Atlantic. We understand that ships which do not find employment here are waiting for weeks to get cargo in the Atlantic until a charterer says, `Okay, I will go for that because I have not got anything else.'

PARA.TAB: People are demanding quality. They are demanding quality from the shipowner, from the manager, from the classification societies, from the insurance companies, all around the business, and if there is high price for quality I think people have come to realise that that price is well worth paying and people do pay a high price for quality because it pays dividends. I think people in the industry are realising that.

SPEECH.PARA: There was total agreement among the steel mills of the major Japanese shipping companies that they will focus on quality. That means that they will not accept ships which are substandard—whatever that word means—and that they will ensure that they do comply with international regulations.

I am using this information given to the committee because those witnesses are the actual users of the ships. It is their cargoes that are going on the ships. These are not the words of some rabid unionist. This is not some politician trying to score a point. These are the decision makers in the commercial world who are speaking.

PARA.TAB: I draw the Committee's attention to a report in the Daily Commercial News of 21 November 1994. Mr Benz referred to the drift of substandard ships into the Atlantic; but some months ago in South America, off one of the ports of Brazil, a substandard iron ore ship that did not meet the international standards was loaded with iron ore. It set sail and trouble developed. The Brazilian port authorities would not allow that vessel back in, because it was so bad that they were fearful that it would sink in their port, thus becoming an obstruction to shipping and fouling the environment. So that vessel was taken out to sea in the South Atlantic and scuttled.

Here is a second one. This is a report of 21 November 1994. The vessel Trade Daring, a 134,999 deadweight ton Cyprus flag vessel, broke its back and sank alongside the principal iron ore berth on 11 November, effectively closing the installation until it could be removed. I will not go into all the detail of the report, but that underlines the point that Mr Benz was making, that there is a gravitation of substandard shipping away from the Pacific over into the Atlantic, and it is probably a good thing because it concentrates those substandard vessels in the one area. They will have more and more difficulty, even if they have been cheap vessels, in getting cargoes, and commercial discipline will apply. And that commercial discipline will be that vessels have to earn their keep. People cannot sit around for six weeks or 10 weeks trying to get a cargo, even if they have got a cheap ship. So commercial discipline will apply and we will see, I hope, a faster departure from the seas of those substandard vessels, with the risks to human life, to crews, that they constitute.

In the other areas of ship safety, we have found that there is continuing abuse of crews, a continuing deprivation and exploitation. I have no doubt in my mind that Filipino employers continue to black-list Filipino seafarers who complain, so the seafarers cannot really speak up. Just to go to Intertanko, I said to Mr Ugland at a hearing on 27 September:

SPEECH.PARA: Your association stresses the use of quality tankers, quality crews?
Mr Ugland—It supports it.
Chair—Your association stresses, or prefers the use of, quality vessels, quality ships?
Mr Ugland—Yes . . . I think all ships need quality crew, and I think it pays. It is not a question of nationality, it is a question of training and motivation.

So there, from Intertanko, the largest tanker organisation in the world, is support for the course that Australia is following. We have been greatly heartened as a committee at the work that we have done. When the original report came down it was horrendous to be adopting the course of investigation we were taking, it was absolutely out of court. How could we have the temerity to be asking about the commercial environment?

PARA.TAB: The matter that I conclude on is the publication of information of ships detained and their deficiencies. That has now been stepped up and widened by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, at the suggestion of our committee. It will do more than anything in the short term to get rid of these vessels, to sweep these vessels from the sea. The actual beneficiaries—the cargo owners, the charterers, shipowners, the classification societies and the ship managers—will all have their names published monthly in respect of ships that are detained in Australian ports. When we recommended that originally, it was heresy. Now it is published more extensively by the US Coast Guard and by the United Kingdom, and Lord Donaldson in his report at the beginning of this year came down very strongly in support of the initiative that we had outlined.

I see getting this information published as a very welcome development. In aviation, if something is wrong with an aircraft, the manufacturer immediately advises all the users of that aircraft. It is public information; it is out there for people using that industry and operating in that industry to be able to respond to and correct that deficiency. But in shipping there has been a veil of secrecy.

I am sure that all members of the committee are very pleased with the progress being made. We will resume the examination of ship safety standards towards the middle of next year. We will have a much more comprehensive report and that report will be the final report to this the 37th Parliament of Australia. We will be able then, looking at what has happened at the International Maritime Organisation, to make some more pertinent and conclusive recommendations in reporting to the parliament. I commend the reports to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McArthur Mr F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I pay tribute to the role of the chairman of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), in proposing the introduction of the report of the former committee, Ships of shame, and the follow-up report which is being tabled in the parliament today. I am delighted to support his remarks. As deputy chairman of the committee, and on behalf of the other committee members, I want to put on the public record my admiration for the enthusiastic approach of the chairman in his attempts to ascertain the facts and to find the truth. He ensured that the Ships of shame report—a very good report—was followed up by this second report, which is a progress report on monitoring of issues in the report of the inquiry into ship safety, and includes the implementation of the earlier recommendations.

PARA.TAB: It is remarkable that a committee of the House of Representatives has had such an impact internationally. Again, I put on the public record that people of significance have looked at the recommendations of this committee and they have followed them through at international level. I will follow that point through shortly, but obviously concerns about old shipping—the number of sinkings and the number of accidents—are matters that the committee looked at during its recent investigations.

It is worth looking at some of the attributes of world shipping. It would cost some $400 billion to replace the vessels that are currently trading around the world. Another interesting feature is that half of the world fleet is on open register, which means that there is less surveillance of the quality and safety standards surrounding those vessels. Also, of course, there is often a more beneficial tax regime. In the tanker trade, 75 per cent of the fleet consists of vessels over the age of 15 years; another very significant fact about which this committee became aware. Australia is the fifth largest exporting nation using sea lanes and sea vessels, and this fact gives a perspective on the importance of international trade and on the use of these vessels in exporting and importing our goods.

I support the chairman in commending the committee's approach in the open forum which was conducted in Sydney on 27 May 1994. All the major players in the maritime industry were present at the forum. The forum was very well conducted by the chairman, and the main players were subject to peer group pressure on the comments they have made on the public record. Following on that particular process, members of the committee were able to ascertain the veracity of some of the statements which were made in front of very learned people: classification society observers; shippers; and representatives from the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. Representatives from these organisations listened to what was said, and they made some pertinent contributions.

I was very interested in the ability of the committee to command international personnel to appear before it as witnesses. BHP ran an international conference called Shipshape in Sydney in September 1994. Prior to that conference, the committee was able to ask a number of world-class players in international shipping to appear before it, so that they could make a contribution about their attitudes to ship safety and the ships of shame. They were: Mr John Horrocks and Mr Ewan Kelly, representing the International Chamber of Shipping; Mr Tony Nunn, representing the Institute of London Underwriters; and Mr Andreas Ugland, representing the Intertanko Company. Mr Ugland is a former chairman of the group to which the chairman referred.

In its appearance before the committee the group raised a number of issues. One of the issues which was raised was the cost of crews; this is one of the most variable costs in running any fleet of tankers or other vessels. Occasionally, international operators cut back on the costs of the crews and the way in which they train and look after them. Another issue which was raised was the training of international crews. The committee received a number of observations from the international personnel and took the opportunity to ask questions on a number of the issues raised: what are the standards; what are the certificates which are issued; and what is the validation of the international training certificates. Obviously, anyone who has an understanding of this issue is concerned, from time to time, that some of the certificates are questionable.

The age and registration of ships is another matter on which the committee heard first-rate evidence; for example, the age of a number of ships now in trade, and what action was being taken about those ships. Insurance and risk was another topic, and Mr Tony Nunn, representing the Institute of London Underwriters, gave a truly international perspective to that topic. Some of the evidence which he tabled at the meeting indicated that the older the ship, the greater the likelihood of accident or collision. There was a suggestion put forward that, rather than there being a subsidy for building ships, there should be a subsidy for scrapping older ships. That is an innovative approach. Significantly, because of increasing environmental standards, the double hull approach for big oil tankers was another issue that was raised.

The credibility of classification societies throughout the world has been under considerable debate by the committee and by witnesses, and these international persons raised that issue, of whether the classification societies—the 11 major ones and other lesser ones—did retain international credibility. I might say, in passing, that informal comment by those witnesses suggested that they found members on this committee had an understanding of the issues and asked the right questions, compared with their experience when they appeared before the United States congressional and senatorial committees where politics was the main issue, rather than trying to seek out the truth and to seek out what was happening at the international level.
Two recommendations sum up our progress to date. I note, for the record, recommendation 3B:

SPEECH.PARA: That appropriate operating criteria for classification societies be devised and that only certificates from classification societies, included when a classification society acts as an agent for a flag state, which comply with those criteria be recognised as valid internationally.

What we are really saying there is that the classification societies should be putting forward valid material in relation to vessels and to the way in which they interpret whether a vessel is seaworthy or less seaworthy, or whether it has some defects. The International Association of Classification Societies has introduced a number of schemes which will improve the performance of these classification societies. Over the time that I have been with the committee, it has had numerous discussions about the ability of classification societies to properly ascertain the seaworthiness, or lack of, of various vessels.

PARA.TAB: The other recommendation that I put on the record is recommendation 4A:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Australian Maritime Safety Authority have access to sufficient funds to increase the rate and effectiveness of Port State Control inspections to a level where it ceases to be viable for substandard shipping to call at Australian ports.

Put in very simple terms, we are saying that the maritime authority should have enough money to make sure that any substandard ships that come to Australian ports are inspected and are held to account. We are putting on the public record that we do not like those sorts of ships coming here and, if they are not up to standard, the Australian authorities will take the necessary action.

PARA.TAB: I would also like to refer briefly, in my capacity as deputy chairman, to the other report that is tabled—The national highway `Lifeline of the nation' and the comments of the National Audit Office.

There is a good relationship between the federal funding authorities and the state authorities who implement the funding and also the construction work using these road funding moneys. The audit committee looked at the highway priorities around Australia; the accountability of the state instrumentalities; the way in which the money moved from the federal coffers to the state treasuries; and the quality and progress of the various road constructions. I particularly note that there was an incentive for savings in the budgeted allocations, which state authorities would gain from, and that matter is under consideration.

In general, that report indicates a movement in the right direction in terms of audit process and spending money efficiently by the federal authorities via the state construction groups. I commend both reports and I hope that, in the next few months, we will have a further report in relation to ship safety that will conclude a remarkable report of international standing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to comment on two reports by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. One is the progress report Review inquiry into ship standards and safety and the other is Efficiency audit review: The national highway `Lifeline of the Nation'.

PARA.TAB: The report on the national highway deals with areas of contention between the Department of Transport and the Australian National Audit Office, which arose following an efficiency audit of management of the national highway scheme, and gets to grips with whether it was being done efficiently or effectively.

There were a number of areas which proved to be inefficient and there seemed to have been little concern by road builders to try to use new methods to reduce overall costs. There appeared to be lack of accountability to anyone about what was spent and how it was spent. Few works programs had been drawn up and little prioritisation had been done, so that roads were inclined to just happen in many places. There was certainly a need to get some auditing into that area.

Some of the planning has been pretty poor in the past and there is a need to do much more in the area of road safety. State governments tend to try to cut corners by leaving out safety precautions, whether they are simple pavement signs, vertical signs and markings, or some of the lines-of-sight designs, and they are very inadequate. I can quote the tragic circumstances which occurred on the Illawarra Highway, a new road in my own electorate, when two people died after a tourist car ran into a local family coming back from Launceston. I can only blame the appalling signage on the road. Much of it was temporary and some of it just was not there at all. Roads should not be open to the public until they are completely ready, because it takes some time for local people to become used to new systems and new schemes. This is very important in regional Australia.

Educating local communities for change should take place. When a road network which has been in place for somebody's lifetime suddenly changes to a national highway, matters of speed, entry and exits on these roads can become very dangerous. Maybe warnings should be issued for the older generation as to what changes are likely to occur with the upgrading of roads. Although it is clear that there has been considerable improvement in the standard of national highways in recent years, there is still room for improvement, particularly translated to a state level.

The committee has been looking at performance indicators and improved information collection as one means of measuring improvements and excellent concepts. But there are some aspects that need to be considered in terms of cutting down the number of road deaths and injuries.

There should be a national road signs code that is binding on all states, so that people driving in any one state in Australia will become familiar with them. There are guidelines now, but everyone seems to have a different way of interpreting them. It is about time there is a national code that is part of the national highway scheme structure and that gives sign distances from intersections, has the same dotted white lines, and the same merging patterns and instructions on all roundabouts. Some of the Tasmanian markings are the most bizarre I have ever seen. We are very good at putting traffic lights on roundabouts and other such nonsenses. There are recommendations in the report to improve the accountability of state authorities through performance agreements and I believe that road design, markings and signs should be a part of that assessment. The review has been very useful and I commend the report to all members of the house.

Like the deputy chairman of this committee, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), the other report I wish to comment on is the progress report of the ship safety review inquiry. This report goes on from the previous report, Ships of shame, which is an international standard report used in other parts of the world to come to grips with this incredible phenomenon of the standard of safe ships in the world. To a great extent this has been driven by the chairman of our committee, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who deserves a great deal of credit for the work that has gone into this.

This progress report continues the work of documentation that went into Ships of shame, which highlighted the issues associated with improving shipping standards and safety. We were requested to continue working with the government to pursue a safer and more responsible international shipping industry by inquiring on an ongoing basis into developments at a national and international level in relation to issues identified in the Ships of shame report.

We have been looking at the implementation of the earlier report's recommendations and advancing some new solutions to ship safety issues. Some of those issues have been incredible. The continued abuse and maltreatment of crews on some ships have been terrible. In an incident which was widely reported, a ship ran aground and the crew had to abandon ship. The ship had Greek officers and had people of two or three other nationalities as crew. In that emergency none of them could really communicate with the others because of their different languages. This came up in evidence that we received through our committee. Such language barriers in those circumstances lead to confusion and panic, and could mean unnecessary loss of life, environmental damage from oil spills and other problems.

We were told in our hearings that some of the officers of ships that have come into Australian ports have been incapable of submitting loading plans to harbourmasters. It is incredible that people have qualifications to take ships around the world, but when they come into Australian ports they cannot submit a loading plan to the harbourmaster. That goes right to the heart of some of the issues on safe shipping. Loading a ship wrongly can put enormous stress on the structure of that ship, which means that it could fail when put under a lot of pressure in heavy seas.

Evidence given has shown that it is very hard to do anything about foreign ships registered in certain countries. That was constantly coming up. We talk of ships being registered in some countries because of the commercial advantages of what are called `flags of convenience'. Those countries should have their flags known internationally as `flags of shame'. If those countries want to put flags on ships which are substandard and put people's lives at risk, then their flags should become known as flags of shame, and we should constantly remind those countries that their flags are being seen as being flags of shame.

Because the International Maritime Organisation really does not have any teeth in the sense of being able to stop a ship from sailing, there has been a great problem in getting ships and shipping companies to comply with international conventions and their requirements. We need some means of giving the International Maritime Organisation the power to act to suspend or expel flag states from conventions with which they do not comply. One way to assist with this is to ensure transparency of action. We need to ensure that those that transgress are reported publicly.

In Australian ports now we are starting to get those publications, and we are starting to get those names appearing. In the United States of America they are doing the same, and I understand that England is now looking at the same concept of naming these ships and companies that do not comply. Then we will get some names up so that it can be seen who they are. Let us do that in a very big way. All the major players, which include shipowners and managers, classification societies, flag states, charterers and cargo owners, should in some way be responsible for the state of a ship and the safety of its crew. Improved performance on all sides will improve the safety of ships worldwide.

Improvements have been made to the technical side of shipping, with bills of lading and the transfer of information. These improvements should lead to a more efficient and cost-effective turnaround of ships. The excuses for hiring substandard ships are no longer valid, because the port authorities are aware of the condition and the availability of ships. Responsible charterers and cargo owners should be well aware of substandard vessels, and they should be able to identify and to avoid using those vessels. If charterers and cargo owners ignore that advice, they should be subject to public exposure.

The general argument about using trained workers—whether it is in manufacturing or whether it is in any other employment—applies in Australia. Trained people who are competent in carrying out their tasks will increase productivity, and there is no reason why the same principle should not apply in world shipping. If competent people maintain ships, those ships will be more productive and, in the long run, they will return a bigger percentage of income to the owners. Although there is a considerable extra cost to owners to use competent, well-trained crew to maintain vessels, in the long term the owners have safer and more productive ships and, therefore, their profit margin increases. This theory is exactly what applies in the rest of our country, and it is our argument for the training of the work force.

Now that the people involved with substandard ships have been identified, there is evidence enough that companies should not have to use substandard vessels. If companies ignore the advice that they receive about substandard vessels, they should be subject to public exposure. Public exposure will ultimately ensure that substandard vessels do not exist in international shipping. The problem is far from solved, but those responsible must ensure that the world has a safe shipping fleet.

Ships come to Australia from all parts of the world, and more countries are becoming involved in shipping. Some of those countries have neither been open to scrutiny nor been accepting of international standards, and their standards will certainly have to improve to meet world shipping standards. If their standards do not improve, authorities should not hesitate to name the country responsible. If ships are substandard, they should fly a flag to be known as the `flag of shame'. That flag should be used to identify and expose substandard ships, and the ships should be named. That action should be taken not only in Australia but around the world. It should be possible to report the shipowners and the shipping companies which do not comply with decent international standards.

The chairman and my fellow committee members have worked hard to put this report together. The report is, of course, part of continuing work and the final report will come down in the new year. I commend the report to this Committee and to all members.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the time I have been in this House it has become apparent to me that committees are very often used by the executive government to keep politicians busy so that they simply do not cause any trouble. Committee members can find that they waste a lot of time in committees, putting in a lot of work and effort when sometimes that work seems as if it is not going to amount to much. I believe that the reports we are dealing with here today are both very different.

PARA.TAB: I must commend the work of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure. I believe the committee has been very well served by its deputy chairman, the honourable member for Corangamite (Mr McArthur), and admirably served by the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), who has been without a doubt a driving force on this committee. I think his experience, his sheer bulldog determination, his vast knowledge and his ability to cut through a lot of hyperbole has been of enormous benefit to the committee and, consequently, to the nation. If we were going to adopt any of the ideas of overseas countries, I think we should give consideration to the Chinese idea and make the honourable member for Shortland a national treasure.

One of the interesting things in the progress report on the ship safety review inquiry is that we were told repeatedly at the start of our evidence gathering, which was very widespread, that we in Australia could not act unilaterally, that we must not act alone and that, if we did, it would have an enormous detrimental effect on trade and we would drive shipping away from Australia. This has proved to be, we believe, nonsense. There was no real evidence to support the claim. In fact, it is quite clear that by demanding standards Australia has achieved for this nation a situation where it is the top 20 or 25 per cent of the world's fleets that come here. Obviously, the ships of lesser quality, the `ships of shame', are going elsewhere. It is incumbent upon other nations to do the same as we have done here to drive them into the scrapyards where they belong.

In looking at this report, it became obvious to us that it had to be a multi-level approach. We had to have the cooperation of shipowners and managers and they had to accept their responsibilities; classification societies had to accept their responsibilities; flag states had to take some interest in the condition of ships that were flying their flags, and not merely collect the money; and the charterers and cargo owners also had a very large responsibility. I think it is true to say that the original report we brought down in December 1992 was the reason that these issues were raised and I think it is generally accepted that the report got international acclaim. It was reviewed on the BBC in the United Kingdom. I know that Readers Digest ran articles in, I think, nine languages based on our report.

The standard of the submissions that came to us in subsequent reviews has improved dramatically. The report is going to make an impact for the benefit not just of Australia but for the world, and for the safety of seamen. There is no doubt that shipowners have in the past taken a view that cheap rates were their opportunity and that, really, they did not have any great responsibility. Cargo owners now—in part, due to our report, I think—recognise that they do have this responsibility. This in itself is going to have a significant effect and impact on the improvement of standards.

One of the other things we found was that, no matter how good the mechanics of a ship were, if the standard of the crew was substandard or inadequate, then the ship was going to be in trouble and it was going to be a potential danger to itself and to other areas. This is really commonsense and everyone should realise that communication is absolutely vital in a ship. For too long it had not been considered and people had been prepared simply to look the other way. It took the commonsense of this report to bring home to people the need for improved crewing standards.

I do not believe those crew standards are anything like high enough yet. They have a long way to go but I think they are rising. The fact that people are aware of them is in large part due to the heavy emphasis that our report gave to this aspect. I think it is incumbent upon all maritime nations to make sure that their ships carrying their crews do have that level of communication. If it is not there, it will simply put their nationals in danger. It will put in danger the environment and it will also put in danger, of course, other people.

The other aspect that we have highlighted is this unilateral action which I mentioned earlier. There is no doubt that port state control reporting is very beneficial. Australia is one of the frontrunners in that. The United Kingdom now has port state control reporting. It has been available in the civil aviation area for a long time. This is also going to make a very big impact. Opening up the whole industry to scrutiny can only have a very beneficial impact on the whole industry.

One of the things that does concern me was an element in some of the submissions we received that was saying that insisting on high standards would raise costs and this would cause us to be uncompetitive. I think this is simply arrant nonsense. I think the report is actually showing that. There is no doubt that people have to pay for a higher standard ship but the cost is not greatly above that of low standard ships. To interpret that into a cost at the end of the day is very hard to do. Efficient, high standard shipping has other benefits. There are cost savings in terms of fewer breakdowns. There are cost savings in terms of more reliable delivery, less demurrage, all those sorts of things. Of course, those benefits are passed on to consumers. I think on balance high quality shipping has cost savings; it does not cost the community.

Let us look at the potential costs to the community of low standard shipping. It is true that an iron ore bulk carrier that goes down—as, sadly, too many of them did—does not have a great environmental impact. Iron ore is not polluting; it is an inert substance. The ships themselves usually do not carry an enormous amount of oil; it will leak out over time probably. Lives are lost. Yes, that is sad but that is somebody else's life and that has no great impact. Let us look at some of the other dangerous cargoes that are carried around the world now; let us look at an accident involving these. I am reminded of the Kirki which lost its bow off the coast of Western Australia. It was only through sheer luck in the tides and the winds that that enormous cargo did not come ashore in Western Australia.

I accept that the polluting qualities of oil are probably being greatly overstated, as is the wont of the environmental lobby. Oil pollution is, nevertheless, a very messy process and a very costly process. If it was toxic chemicals instead of oil, the consequences could be far more severe. So I believe any nation, as a simple insurance policy, should ensure that any cargoes carried off its shores that are of a toxic nature or could be of long-term detriment to the environment should be carried in ships of very high standard. It would seem to me to go without saying that it is in the national interest to make sure that does occur.

The other thing that I think the Ships of shame report does not touch on but which needs to be highlighted is that it needs to be said over and over again that Australia is a maritime nation. On a per capita basis, we are one of the countries most involved in shipping in the world. It is beholden upon us in our national interest to have a very viable shipping industry. A nation like Australia should never have its shipping entirely in the hands of foreign interests as we do at the moment. It is simply a matter of insurance that Australia has a viable and large efficient transport service.

The reality is that we are competitive with all developed countries. We should not be expected to compete with low standard ships, whose undertrained, underpaid Third World crews present enormous dangers. Our report did not directly touch on that, but it is a conclusion that can certainly be drawn from the information we have gathered. A very high standard maritime industry is important for this nation. It goes without saying there will be immediate benefits to the current account if we were to carry more of our products on Australian ships.

The other report I want to deal with is the report on the national highway, Lifeline of the nation. It was overshadowed by the acclaim and world recognition received by Ships of shame. It is, nevertheless, a very workmanlike document that brings together the threads in trying to understand where Australia is heading in national highway construction. I wish to highlight the need for an audit of the national highway and the distribution of priorities. For too long, Australia had a situation where population demand has determined where roads are built. We continually tend to build superhighways and bypass roads around our coastal cities, whilst neglecting the clear demands for roads in less populated areas. Roads built in those areas would enhance the national interest by encouraging the rapid production of export wealth for the nation.

The truth is that if a bypass road around Perth, the capital city of my own state, has any benefit at all in terms of efficiency to industry, that benefit is hard to quantify. It certainly would not be taken into calculation in any job tendering or quoting. On the other hand, roads built through areas of mineral potential would open up new mining potential and produce a clear and immediate benefit to the whole nation. We did try to look at that in the report.

I am pleased to say that this government has changed the priorities, or the form of assessment. Formerly, we had a situation where the Commonwealth government allocated the money, but the states said where the priorities were and where the roads were to be built. The state authorities were doing it entirely on a traffic count basis. We introduced a requirement for the development of potential roads to be taken into consideration. This has helped in some way—although not enough, in my view—to redirect road construction into those areas where it will create the most wealth for the country.I believe both reports are good. I have been proud to serve on the committee. I certainly commend the staff of the committee and all those members who participated in it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I acknowledge the comments that have been made about the chair of the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). He certainly has become a legend in his own day, or a legend in the life of this parliament. The Ships of shame report was produced before I entered the parliament; it was tabled in December 1992, and it has become a report of national and international significance. This was evidenced in the most recent ships safety review and the degree to which our inquiry excited the ongoing interest of industry. It is a tribute to the respect that industry has for the honourable member for Shortland and for the work that he has done in this area.

PARA.TAB: As I mentioned, the report is of international significance as well as of national significance. That was typified by the conference that was held by BHP—the `Shipshape' conference—on 27 and 28 September this year where we saw the largest gathering of shipping interests ever assembled in Australia. I think that is evidence of international interest in a report produced by this particular parliament. The recommendations of the ship safety review need to be taken very seriously by the government. There is still much to be done in this area. It was obvious from the hearings that I attended in relation to this review that we were settling in for the long haul as far as improving ship's safety was concerned. I pay particular tribute to the honourable member for Shortland and other members of the committee for their enduring interest and work in this very important area.

The second report I would like to comment on is report of the Sydney Olympics inquiry. Committee members and members of the Committee will note that in its terms of reference the committee was asked to inquire into the communications and transport infrastructure requirements of the Sydney Olympics. That inquiry dealt mainly with the adequacy of existing and planned aviation services and other infrastructure. I am quite fortunate in that I also sit on the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology. We have been looking at ways in which Australian industry might participate more fully in the Sydney Olympics and at ways to get benefits for the Australian economy from that industry participation.

It is important to note that this report on the requirements for the Sydney Olympics deals mainly with transport infrastructure requirements. The committee did not deal with the communications area. It took the view that communications technology was moving at a rapid pace and that, since there were such significant developments occurring in communications technology, it would be better for the committee to examine these particular issues a bit later.

As I said, the report mainly focused on aviation infrastructure requirements. The committee had some difficulty in the definition of terms, the assembling of data and in making some sense of the various forecasts that had been made by various agencies. However, we did come to the conclusion that unless the infrastructure problems at Kingsford Smith airport were addressed there would be some real danger that the airport would not be able to cope with the pressure that would come on it at the time of the Sydney Olympics. The honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis) obviously has a burning interest in this particular issue and I think he would be of the view that the airport does not have the infrastructure now to cope with the traffic that is going through. I had cause to attend a meeting in Melbourne the other day, and a particular person was late for the meeting because the plane spent about 45 minutes on the tarmac at Kingsford Smith airport before it was able to take off.

As the honourable member for Shortland noted in his tabling remarks, one particular thrust of the committee has largely been overtaken by the discussion that is now taking place around the construction of Badgerys Creek. If that particular development is to proceed, and no doubt it will, within the time frame that we have set for the Olympics, the problems that we have identified at Kingsford Smith airport may not materialise.

Let me pick up on the recommendation that relates to the ancillary infrastructure that feeds that airport. It is obvious from the evidence that was presented that certainly the road infrastructure needs some critical examination and attention. The problems with getting into Kingsford Smith airport are quite significant and that is one issue that will have to be addressed. The committee has made a recommendation that will address that problem in a bit greater detail in the context of the report.

I really enjoyed working with the committee members on the various reports. I would like to thank the chair for his tolerance in dealing with new members of parliament. Obviously, we are on a steep learning curve in these inquiries. We are asked to get on the front foot and to become involved in the proceedings to make judgments about the evidence that is presented. That can be a daunting task to a new member. It is very comforting to have older members, and members who have been around this parliament for a while, giving us guidance. I thank the honourable member for Shortland for the guidance that he has given me and other first term members.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to speak on the progress report on the Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure inquiry into ship standards and safety. I am pleased to speak on it because I have had a long-term interest in shipping, representing, as I do, Port Kembla, one of the great ports along the Australian seaboard, and also being on the board of management of the Missions to Seamen.

PARA.TAB: I do not think it is too extravagant a claim to say that the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Transport, Communications and Infrastructure has put shipping on the world's agenda. People were aware of shipping; ships are always along our coastline. But some people knew about, and others would not talk about, the condition of many of these ships and the problem of shipping not only around the Australian coastline but also throughout the world.

During the time the committee took evidence, and when its first report was brought down, it received worldwide attention. The report highlighted not only the deplorable conditions of the ships that travel through Australian waters—rust, decks painted and covered with canvas, no safety equipment or proper standards—but also the exploitation of the ships' crews—their abuse, both sexual and physical, and their lack of wages. It was a sorry tale, indeed a disgraceful tale, that led to a new expression `ships of shame.'

It is true to say that, since the tabling of the first report, shipping has received much more publicity. That is because people are taking more and more interest in the condition of ships and, indeed, in the condition of the crews on the ship. When members of the Maritime Union speak of the condition of shipping, they are no longer roundly abused by the farming or the mining interests as used to be the case in the past. I remember talking in the House about the condition of ships in Port Kembla—I gave the example of a Chinese ship that was detained there—and being abused by members of the opposition who were mouthpieces for the farmers of Australia. They were prepared to see their cargo go out in deplorable ships that were crewed by people under deplorable conditions. The crew were half-fed and half-starved. As one of the other speakers said, how can ships be decent if they do not have a properly trained, properly maintained and respected crew?

It is important that there be a watching brief on both local and international shipping. This is especially important in Australia because it is an island continent and is more dependent on shipping than most. For a whole host of reasons, the world's shipping fleet is ageing. Replacement ships are not being built. Crews and officers are not being adequately trained and this will have an impact on Australia.

The member for Corio (Mr O'Connor) said it was a long haul. Indeed, it is a long haul and all the nonsense I hear in this parliament about selling off our national line, which carries less than five per cent of our cargo anyway, really frustrates me. What we should be doing in Australia, instead of talking about selling off our national line and selling off our lifeline, is talking about building ships here.

People talk to me about the cost of building ships in Australia. For two years running in the summer break, at my own expense, I have been in Denmark. Denmark, which has got a wage structure as high as, if not higher than, Australia, has a very rewarding shipbuilding industry. It uses modern technology, it is professional at it. We could do that. We could build ships here, as we have shown in many other things, but we do not do that. We just say, `Oh, well, it's far too expensive to build ships in Australia.'

Even if there were a massive worldwide shipping construction industry put in place tomorrow, it would still mean that within the next 10 to 15 years there will be a shortage of ships and there will be a shortage of officers and properly trained ratings. With so many competing interests on shore, the ocean, or going down to the sea in ships, no longer holds the appeal or attraction it once did—indeed, only a few years ago. Given the ageing of the world shipping fleet and the lack of proper training, it is inevitable that supervisory authorities, such as the Australian Maritime Safety Authority, will have to be ever more vigilant. To give credit where it is due, over the past few years AMSA has became much more vigilant and has more properly targeted inspections.

I was particularly concerned that the government did not accept the recommendations of the committee to deny entry of ships that do not meet ILO 147 standards concerning crew employment conditions. The government considered it was impossible to assess whether a ship complied with ILO 147 until it was already in port. Therefore, ships could not be prevented from trading in Australian waters.

This was a cop-out for the government. The number of ships that have been here and have been detained because they do not meet ILO 147 is evidence that there are a lot of ships out there, and what the government is saying concerning ILO 147 is hardly a deterrent.

We have a particular problem in Australia with shipping, especially up in the north and the north-west. We have foreign owned, foreign flagged and foreign crewed ships coming here for a very brief period to pick up a cargo and go out. There is some argument about whether we have the power to impose conditions on those ships and whether it would be better if that happened in the flag state. The fact is that the flag states, for reasons best known to themselves, do not impose conditions. If a ship which was in a disgraceful condition went down off the Australian coast and polluted it, it would be the Australian taxpayers who would pick up the tab, despite all the legislation.

I agreed very much with the member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell)—I do not always agree with the member for Kalgoorlie—when he was talking about some of the other substances that ships are carrying. The Kirki made spectacular television footage. When we saw the television coverage of it we thought how good it was that the television cameras could get so close from the helicopters. We have all made speeches in this House. I sometimes think that, if the Kirki incident had not happened, half a dozen of us would not have had anything to speak about for the last two years, we have spoken about it so frequently.

There is an even more insidious cargo going up and down the Australian coastline, that is, some chemicals. If chemicals went into the water, it would not be spectacular television as happened in the Kirki because no one would really see the result, but the impact on the maritime environment, on the seashore, on the Barrier Reef, on the fish would be much worse. That is a very important thing that we have to watch carefully.

A lot of people were very sceptical when we started this inquiry. No-one knows that better than the chairman of the committee, the honourable member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris). In fact, an editorial appeared in Lloyd's List. Is that not wonderful—a group of Australian politicians subject to an editorial in Lloyd's List? Basically, it said, `What would this group of colonial politicians know about shipping? It will be a knee-jerk reaction. They will do this. They will do that.' That editorial gave us a serve. During my trip to Scandinavia, everyone I talked to about shipping showed me that editorial. What happened when we brought out our report? We made the editorial of that very same paper, Lloyd's List, but this time it was praising us for the work we had done and the contribution we had made to international shipping.

People say, `Yet another committee has been established', but the work we do can make an important contribution. I believe that this progress report has made a significant contribution to shipping, not only in Australia but worldwide. It is respected worldwide. We have brought a new term into usage: ships of shame. Wherever we go they use the term `ships of shame'. In England they talk about their ships of shame.

I remember sitting with the honourable member for Shortland one day and asking, `Peter, what are we going to call this report?' He said, `We are going to call it Ships of shame.' The committee highlighted that. This report has made an important contribution, but we cannot rest on our laurels. The condition of shipping is far too important. Hopefully, the work of the committee will continue under the able chairmanship of the honourable member for Shortland. I hope that I will be able to remain a member of the committee. I commend the report to the House.
Debate (on motion by Mr Bradford) adjourned.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs Committee

PARA.TAB: Debate resumed from 5 December, on motion by Ms Henzell:
That the House take note of the report.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Henzell Ms M.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to have the opportunity to continue the remarks I was making in the House on Monday when we tabled the report of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs entitled Justice under scrutiny: report of the inquiry into the implementation by governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. We may have a little more time today to speak to the report, but I certainly do not want to cut into the time available to my colleague the honourable member for Grey (Mr Wakelin), whom I injudiciously did not allow to speak in the House during the tabling of the report the other day.

PARA.TAB: There has been quite a lot of response in the media to the tabling of this report. In a press release, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) described the committee's report as:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . an invaluable assessment of the progress in dealing with the recommendations of one of this country's most important national enquiries.
He went on to say:

. . . my referral to the committee of Government reports on responses to the Royal Commission's recommendations and the establishment of the position of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner were initiatives going far beyond what the Royal Commission itself recommended in the area of public accountability.

PARA.TAB: I will continue to press for the action that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people rightly demand as a response of the Royal Commission's findings.

SPEECH.PARA: The shadow spokesperson on Aboriginal affairs, the honourable member for Hindmarsh (Mrs Gallus), said the committee `has made a serious and painstaking effort to assess government's response to the recommendations'.

PARA.TAB: However, our committee's report is not being met with universal approval, and I hope that other colleagues on the committee will speak about this more in depth. I refer to the reporting of our committee's report in the Courier-Mail of 6 December with the headline `Police branded racist'. That provoked a not unexpected response from Queensland. The president of the Queensland Police Union branded our report as absolute garbage, in spite of the fact that he had not seen it. Both the minister and the police commissioner expressed considerable reservations. Commissioner O'Sullivan said, `I wonder how many law-abiding citizens within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community were interviewed'.

It is my understanding that all of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people who appeared before the inquiry were law-abiding citizens, and they in no way abused law and order during the hearings—not only those in Queensland but all over the country. I am reminded of the situation when we held a public hearing in Sydney. A large number of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and other community supporters found themselves outside the legislative chambers in Sydney. There was considerable concern expressed that there would be a riot, and at the behest of the Speaker of the New South Wales Legislative Assembly the parliamentary officers were seriously considering closing the parliament. It was my concern as chair of the committee that that would indeed provoke a riot.

While I was negotiating with the speaker of the New South Wales house, I returned to find that all of the community people had filed in peaceably and were sitting in the public room—or standing, because they had run out of seats—in a very peaceable way. They were displaying some signs and so on, but there was at no stage any disorder, such was their commitment to making sure that the inquiry went ahead.

Unfortunately, in spite of members of the Queensland Police Service and the minister not having had an opportunity to look at the full report but relying solely on the clippings and some of the material that we had faxed up to them, I am afraid to say that the police minister found the report `shoddy, superficial and silly'. It is his view that the people who wrote the report are destined to remain on the backbench forever. I am glad that the future careers of all the federal parliamentarians who worked very hard and most diligently on this report are in the hands of their relevant caucus groups in this place. I would hope that, in spite of the reaction from Queensland, on mature reflection and on an opportunity to really go through the report they will see the value of the constructive criticism that we have made.
The Courier-Mail in its editorial of the 6th said:

SPEECH.PARA: The federal parliamentary committee report . . . clearly must be taken seriously . . . the police response to the Roma St affray that followed the death of Daniel Yock . . . is a touchy area. The police themselves, having probed the circumstances of that unfortunate breach of the peace at the Transit Centre, must realise they have not emerged covered with glory.

Although it makes some criticisms of us, the final comment in the editorial is that `the police should be willing to open their door to the inquiry'. In response to certain criticisms that have been levelled at us by Queensland, we based our criticisms on the official report of the Queensland Police Service which is entitled Report of the investigation into the incident on 8 November 1993 involving members of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community and police personnel outside police headquarters.

PARA.TAB: Indeed, it was not about whether `Aboriginal' is put in lower or upper case but serious concerns about the position of cross-cultural policing in Queensland state, of which the report states:

SPEECH.PARA: This document has not been sanctioned by our Service at this time.
It went on to say:

Observations made by members of the Review Committee during interviews showed Inspector . . . and Senior Sergeant . . . as being mentally and emotionally conditioned to the perceived plight of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait islander people. Their concerns and leanings appeared to be towards total commitment to the needs of those people.
Those making the report obviously have a concern and they have made the following recommendation under the heading `Recommendations arising from defects in police procedures':
2.3 Cross-Cultural Support Service members serve a maximum of 2 years in that role to safeguard members against familiarity and excessive personal and emotional interaction and contact.

So there is real concern about the attitude of senior police officers. We are hoping that our constructive criticisms will be taken in that line as a challenge to improve the changes that have already been made in the Queensland Police Service and not be rejected out of hand as garbage. But I am pleased that we have had at least that reaction because we have not had a great deal of response from other states. At least I have now seen the Western Australian report in the West Australian of 6 December that we have been reported and I understand that there will be a further report coming down.

PARA.TAB: I do not want to take time from other members of the committee, but we had very disturbing accounts of over-policing and abusive practices in Western Australia. We have drawn clear attention to the meal allowance policy, which seems to be a very positive encouragement to arrest people, and we have drawn attention to the over-policing in places such as Wiluna and Roebourne, as we have drawn attention to the more positive community police relations in places like Kalgoorlie. I just want to make a comment on a report from the Aboriginal Legal Service of Western Australia that we took in our evidence about both over-policing and using street offences to clear the streets of Aboriginal people. I quote from chapter 8, 8.70:

SPEECH.PARA: Many of the charges for street offences were for quite trivial matters. The committee heard of an elderly woman in court for urinating in a public park at 2 a.m. The magistrate pointed to the triviality, in that the only people who could see her committing this act in the dark were policemen with torches. She was nonetheless convicted and fined $5.00.

This is one example of the sort of harassment and unnecessary over-policing that occurs on a regular basis in Western Australia. Indeed, we heard in New South Wales of similar harassment of Aboriginal people, from Sydney through to Wilcannia. These situations must be attended to. I hope there will be a great deal of community discussion, dialogue and debate about this very considerable report that all members of the committee worked extremely hard on. The evidence on which we based our criticisms and our recommendations is included in the report so that it can be totally transparent.

PARA.TAB: I hope that the report will be taken with the seriousness which it deserves and responded to not only by the federal government but by all state and territory governments. I thank the hardworking secretariat and members of the committee for their cooperation. I will leave it to my fellow committee members now to address the report with their concerns.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wakelin Mr B.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of the deputy chair of the committee, the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), I speak as an opposition member of the committee on the tabling of this report from the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs entitled Justice under scrutiny: report of the inquiry into the implementation by governments of the recommendations in the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. Firstly, I would like to thank my fellow members and particularly thank the committee staff: Allan Kelly, who is in the committee room currently, and the inquiry staff, Craig Dukes, Gabrielle Jess, Penne Humphries and Peter Ratas.

PARA.TAB: The Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody produced a report addressing not only the immediate circumstances of deaths in custody, and that was in December 1988 with an interim report from Justice Muirhead, but also the underlying issues that affect the daily lives of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people—health, water supply, housing, education, literacy and subsequent life options.

The final report with its 339 recommendations came down late in 1991 and the government response was in March 1992. We are now in December 1994. I hope the government will be able to live up to its response period because we have recommended that responses be made within three months. I understand it is a commitment of this current government that it will respond to this report within the three-month guideline.

In its inquiry the committee was keen to ensure that the royal commission's report and its recommendations were not allowed to gather dust on a shelf but that they continue to be implemented. With that in mind, I am reminded of the comments of the honourable member for Kalgoorlie (Mr Campbell) about the use of parliamentary committees. Let us trust that this report does not gather dust.

It has been a privilege to work on this bipartisan committee. It is worth having a look at some of the detail. The first point I would like to document is the number of areas of government, state and federal, that are involved with the implementation of the recommendations. There is the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General, the Australasian Police Ministers Council, the Corrective Service Ministers Conference, and the Ministerial Council on Drug Strategy which I really do hope can lift its game because there is much to be done in that area and I have not been impressed personally by what I have seen thus far.
