There is also the Ministerial Council on Education, Employment, Training and Youth Affairs, the Health and Community Services Ministerial Council, the Standing Committee on Agriculture and Resource Management, the Tourism Ministers Council, the Australian Standing Committee on Tourism and the national supply group. That is the spread of government that is involved in the implementation of the royal commission.
The monitoring process is important to ensure ongoing implementation and to ensure that the implementation is consistent with the thrust and spirit of the 339 recommendations of the royal commission.

The committee found that in theory there was quite a lot of monitoring taking place but not much change in reality for Aboriginal people. Much of our report is based on the criticism of Aboriginal people themselves. For example, the following agents were charged with the task for monitoring the implementation of the royal commission recommendations. They include ATSIC's Royal Commission Government Response Monitoring Unit, ATSIC regional councils, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet—and I must say that I felt that they were struggling with this issue—the Standing Group of Commonwealth Representatives, Social Justice Commissioner Mick Dodson, state based Aboriginal justice advisory committees, and in some states these have not been thus far put into place, state/territory monitoring units, deaths in custody watch committees and the Australian Institute of Criminology's National Deaths in Custody Monitoring and Research Unit.

There are 20 to 30 separate bodies. As I said, a lot of monitoring is going on. Anyone would think that we would be starting to get it right but perhaps it may also be a case of too many cooks spoiling the broth. In fact, we are not getting it right.

The committee found that a number of important recommendations were not being fully implemented and that other recommendations were not being implemented at all. The royal commission stressed the need for indigenous people to be consulted at every stage of the implementation process. However, we heard of a number of examples where consultations had not occurred and, indeed, where some organisations falsely claimed that they had consulted widely.

The royal commission also recommended that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations be involved wherever possible. This has not been done as extensively as it should be and in some cases it has not been done at all. The royal commission sought the establishment in each state and territory of an independent Aboriginal justice advisory committee to provide each government with advice on Aboriginal perceptions of criminal justice matters and implementation of its recommendation. As I have mentioned, that is quite variable.

An area of interest to this committee for many years has been the development of procedures that will allow Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander organisations to account to government for their funding properly but least onerously and in a manner as convenient as possible for those organisations to fulfil. We found that indigenous organisations were still being `funded to fail' because they did not have adequate financial or managerial skills or training. In our recommendation 15 we have outlined our response to recommendation 197 of the royal commission, suggesting that that area should be improved very considerably.

In recommendation 193 the royal commission also pointed out that accountability could be very much improved. However, the federal government, particularly the Department of Finance, has failed to implement this recommendation, despite giving unqualified support to do so. As state and territory governments have said they will look favourably on implementing procedures developed by the federal government, this delay by the federal government is inexcusable.

I mentioned earlier that the committee listened to submissions which took in wide-ranging issues facing Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islanders. In that context I have already mentioned my concern about the national drug strategy. Obviously, there is a link between the abuse of drugs—whether it be alcohol or other substances—the role of the police, the crime rate and, of course, the custody rate. It seems to me there has been a total inadequacy in this area.

One of the health issues we looked at was the hearing condition otitis media, which is generally brought on by cold, flu or chest infection. In fact, we devoted a whole chapter to it, an indication of the degree of importance of this health issue. The infection causes the tube that connects the ear and nose to swell, which stops the normal drainage and ventilation of the middle ear. It reduces the flow of sound to the child, and hearing is reduced.

The committee learnt that this is a large-scale problem in indigenous communities, with some communities reporting that up to 98 per cent of children were affected. It is estimated that otitis media is 10 times more common in indigenous communities that in non-Aboriginal communities. In that context, it is worth quoting from the report at dot point 12.10:

SPEECH.PARA: In a submission to the Royal Commission, the then Commonwealth Department of Community Services and Health, National Acoustic Laboratories, estimated that between 25% and 50% of the 7,500 Aboriginal school children in Northern Territory Aboriginal Schools had a hearing loss caused by chronic Otitis Media. Based on evidence presented to the Committee, this would appear to be a conservative estimate, as it was often quoted that the incidence of Otitis Media was between 80% and 98%.

How many of us can imagine how a child is affected by hearing loss in a learning situation? It can result in not only significant learning disabilities and a loss of confidence in the school system; it can result in leaving school early.

PARA.TAB: Although it was not within the scope of the report to consider, the committee found that governments had not seriously addressed the issue. The committee recommended that the Prime Minister (Mr Keating) and the Council of Australian Governments develop an approach to prevent, screen and treat otitis media. We recommended that schools be prepared to deal with the condition in Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander children. We look forward to the government taking on board that recommendation.

In conclusion, I point out that the key element is still the degree of commitment of governments and departments, and their willingness and capacity to consult effectively with indigenous organisations. Otherwise, we have to consider the effect on Aboriginal communities and ultimately their own commitment to self-help that this failure to come to terms with those 339 recommendations of the royal commission will have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Gibson Mr G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —As chair of the full committee of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, I am delighted to have the opportunity to speak today on this report, Justice under scrutiny: report of the inquiry into the implementation by governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I commend the members of the subcommittee, chaired so ably by my colleague the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), who did an outstanding job in pulling this report together. The report, of course, is the report and recommendations of the full committee but the subcommittee of five members—the member for Capricornia as chair and the member for Cowper (Mr Nehl), the member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown), the member for Cowan (Mr Richard Evans) and the member for Oxley (Mr Les Scott)—did an outstanding job holding the hearings and visiting communities around the country talking to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people as well as government departments and bringing this report together. My congratulations to those members.

PARA.TAB: I think this is a very important report. I am disappointed with the fact that people who have not yet read the report have already come out in public and attacked its findings. Firstly, that is an immature process and, secondly, it does them no credit as important people in the community when they have been prepared to reject the findings of a very important report before they have even had the chance to read it.

Before I talk about the report itself, I might comment on some of the media presentations. The Queensland Police Union has described the report as `garbage' before it has even had a chance to read it and know what it says. It relied solely on a limited press report which my colleague the member for Capricornia indicated was in the Courier-Mail on Tuesday, 6 December. The union was unaware that several very senior police in fact gave evidence to our committee. It has claimed that we have not spoken to police and yet, if we actually look at the transcripts of evidence that this committee has received, we in fact spoke to senior Queensland police officers in the Queensland parliamentary building. The inquiry was advertised nationally, including in the Australian newspaper, and we received no submission from the Queensland Police Union even though the major bulk of this report was about issues that the Queensland Police Union should have been involved with.

Commissioner O'Sullivan, the Commissioner of the Queensland Police Service, said he was upset by the report but he also had obviously not even read it. Mr O'Sullivan is reported as saying, `I wonder how many law-abiding citizens within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Island community were interviewed?' I can assure Mr O'Sullivan, as my colleagues did, that all of the people whom we interviewed were law-abiding citizens. They were important leaders of the Aboriginal communities in Cairns and in Brisbane.

In his comments, Mr O'Sullivan is attempting to slur Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander witnesses to the inquiry. It is a very grubby action by him. It is something that I reject and I find totally inappropriate for a commissioner of police. In fact, what it does is reinforce the very message we were making in this report, that senior officers of the Queensland police do seem to have a problem dealing with their own attitudes towards Aboriginal people.

The police minister, Paul Braddy, has claimed that the committee heard only from complainants without hearing the police side. Again, I absolutely reject that criticism. When our subcommittee visited Cairns, its members had the opportunity to speak to police officers in Cairns. In fact, when the subcommittee came to Brisbane to have hearings with the Queensland government, there were two senior police officers as part of the Queensland government delegation that came to give evidence and answer questions from our subcommittee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Representing the police commissioner.

—Exactly. Deputy Commissioner Banham was representing the Queensland police commissioner there. It is a pity that the police commissioner and the police minister have not in fact checked with their own department about who spoke to our committee before they went into the newspaper and started criticising us. Minister Braddy also said that the report appeared to portray police as not being interested in working with Aborigines. If he had actually read the report instead of relying purely on limited press reports, he would have seen that the committee drew attention to some very successful police-Aboriginal relations occurring in Innisfail. I make the point that, wherever we were given information about improvements or positive changes that had occurred, we have commended the police services in Queensland and in other states for achieving those improvements. Mr Braddy is also reported by AAP as saying:

SPEECH.PARA: This year's state budget doubled the current 47 Aboriginal police liaison officers to 94 and Aborigines were on the selection committee.
So when any committee is reporting on the modern phenomenon of relations between police and Aborigines you would expect to find that information reported as well.

Again, Mr Braddy has not read the report because we have, in fact, included that information in the report on pages 260 and 261. Mr Braddy clearly has little idea of what is in the report that he is so vociferous in rejecting.

PARA.TAB: Mr Braddy has also claimed that the police internal report on the Roma Street incident, which we have included in our report, was the report of one officer. If Mr Braddy was at all familiar with the operations of his own Queensland police service, he would have known that there were five members of the review team, headed by Assistant Commissioner G. Williams who were responsible for that report.

Mr Braddy claims that neither he nor the commissioner were asked for input. Again, I reinforce the fact that our committee wrote to the Premier of Queensland on 7 March 1994 seeking a submission to the inquiry. We wrote again on 8 June inviting government representatives to appear at a public hearing, which they did. The committee took evidence from the state government, including from the Acting Deputy Commissioner of Police.

TALK.START.PARA: —And we sent the transcripts back.
—We have, in fact, sent the transcripts back—I thank the member for Capricornia for reminding me of that point.

PARA.TAB: The committee is concerned about the lack of effective implementation of many of the royal commission's recommendations. Deficiencies were identified in the implementation by all governments, Commonwealth, state and territory. While the report focused primarily on deficiencies in the implementation process, this was with a view to having those deficiencies addressed. That was the whole point of our report. The purpose of us having the terms of reference was to find out where the deficiencies by governments, at the Commonwealth and at the state and territory levels, were occurring so that we could get the public debate going and try to improve that. We are seeking to improve government implementation of the recommendations that all state and territory governments and the Commonwealth have supported. They have supported 338 of the 339 recommendations, and they have an obligation to act to implement their commitments.

The rejection of the report by senior Queensland police and ministers before reading it typifies, in fact, the very attitudinal problems that the committee has criticised in the report. A more informed and constructive approach is desperately required if the royal commission recommendations are to be effectively implemented. There is an important process that we have recommended in our report in order to achieve a better implementation process. One of the major series of recommendations that we have outlined is for a new special unit—a monitoring and evaluation unit—to be established under the auspices of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Social Justice Commissioner. We believe it is very important not to just have government departments at state and Commonwealth level sending in sheets of paper saying, `This is what we've done. This is our track record, as we claim it.' We have to have someone independent looking at those statements, evaluating them, and talking to Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people and organisations to find out whether the statements of the government departments are actually a true and accurate record of what is occurring.

At the moment, there is no true evaluation of these statements. The only evaluation that has occurred is through this committee and we do not believe that it is appropriate that this committee should have to do this every year, 12 months after a report is tabled. We believe that that evaluation and that monitoring should be going on all the time, as an ongoing part of those government departments' implementation of the report. So we believe it is vital that a new special unit be established to ensure that there is effective, ongoing evaluation of all of the government departments. I might make the point that we have been critical of our own Commonwealth government and of a number of our Commonwealth departments as well. We are not letting anybody off the hook; we have commended government departments where they have done the right thing and we have criticised them where we believe they have not acted sufficiently.

The thing that we were quite annoyed about, particularly in reading the implementation reports of the Commonwealth and a number of states, is that quite a number of the government responses to individual recommendations were, in fact, totally irrelevant to the actual royal commission recommendations that they were supposed to be commenting on. The royal commission had given a direction about a certain process that it felt should happen and the government, in writing its report about how it had implemented it, totally ignored what the recommendation was about and talked about something else altogether.

If there was a proper evaluation occurring, that would not be put in those implementation reports. That is why we believe it has got to stop; we have to have a much better evaluation and monitoring process, and it is absolutely crucial that Aboriginal and Islander people and organisations are involved in that process. Without that, there can be really no credibility in the implementation reports.

I would like to make the final point that it is crucial that governments at Commonwealth, state and territory level read the full report. I say to them not to reject its findings before they have had the opportunity to read what we have had to say. It is too important an issue and too important for us, as a country which espouses a great commitment to human rights, to ignore this very crucial issue in our own operation and delivery of human rights for people in this country. I urge the governments of the Commonwealth and all states and territories to read this report carefully, to implement the recommendations and to respond positively to it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in this debate to discuss Justice under scrutiny: report of the inquiry on implementation by governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I have been in parliament now for about 18 months, maybe a bit longer, and I have been on two inquiries with the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I find the comments of the member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) about human rights quite specific in relation to this particular committee because it is a humbling experience to travel to a number of Aboriginal communities around the countryside talking to Aboriginals about their basic needs and the problems they have with basic living standards.

PARA.TAB: During this particular committee inquiry, I was almost convinced by government members—federal and state governments—that there is nothing wrong with the Aboriginal community in Australia, that there are no problems: no criminal problems, no health problems, no education problems and no housing problems. We met delegation after delegation from governments saying that they are doing all these wonderful things and implementing all the recommendations. Yet, when we actually go out into the communities and out into Australia we see no results from any of this at all. I think it is a bit rich, as the member for Moreton was saying, that people say that there is nothing wrong and then bag our report, before they even read it. There are some serious, major problems in relation to the Aboriginal issue within Australia. They do not seem to be getting addressed by anyone.

As I said, we have been on two inquiries. The report of the first one was Rhetoric or reality? and was about the access and equity of Aboriginal communities into mainstream services within government. We presented this to the parliament 12 months ago, but we still have no response by the federal government. Yet I read some reports that the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) was very concerned about this report being tabled and was saying, `Yes, we must do something about it.' We have not even had a response on last year's important human rights issues of equity and access to mainstream services. We have had no response back from the government. It is not just the federal government, it is not just the Queensland government; it is the New South Wales, Victorian, South Australian, Western Australian and Tasmanian governments—and even the Northern Territory government. They are not being responsible and implementing the recommendations. If they are, there is no evidence of that. I think they have to stand up and be more responsive to what we have been recommending.

We have a number of leaders within the Aboriginal community who are very frustrated about what is happening. They hear about all this royal commission money going here and going there, but they see no evidence of it. They put recommendations through—

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —Before going to the division in the chamber, I was talking about the lack of action by governments. It is basically well known—by our committees, certainly; and, we hope, by the broader community generally, through our report—that there is nothing really happening of any serious nature with Aboriginal affairs in Australia. There is a lot of politicking about Aboriginal affairs, whether by the Aboriginal people themselves or by the broader community. People like to play politics; but what we are really doing when we do not take any action at all is playing off people's rights.

PARA.TAB: People talk about Aboriginal rights an awful lot. I do not think that this issue has anything to do with Aboriginal rights, but it has got a lot to do with basic human rights, as the honourable member for Moreton (Mr Gibson) was saying earlier. Recommendation 9.39 on page 213 of our report asks the Commonwealth government to introduce legislation within six months to `protect the rights of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander peoples in accordance with Article 14, Clauses (a) (b) and (f) of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights.' Six months is not a long time for this government. Honourable members might recall the Tasmanian privacy issue. Legislation was developed very quickly there; and there is no reason why we cannot introduce legislation quickly within this place to give Aboriginal people their basic human rights when dealing with courts.

The interpreter services in court are absolutely appalling for Aboriginal people. We need to address that problem and take some action on it. But we are getting the reverse of action: there is no action happening. We are getting a lot of reports done and there is a lot of talk, but there is no action; which makes one think that there must be something structurally wrong with the whole process. Maybe we did not set it up correctly years ago, when we started playing politics with this whole issue. The whole structure needs to be addressed, because the area of greatest need is the area suffering the greatest lack of human rights.

We need to address this problem and find some positive solutions to it. We hope that this report, by discussing the royal commission into black deaths in custody, in some small way goes towards doing that. Along with rights come responsibilities and, depending on where one is in Australia, there are differing attitudes about what sort of responsibility is required from the Aboriginal people. For instance, people in Western Australia have a very different attitude from that of people in, say, Victoria, to things Aboriginal. So reconciliation is a very complex issue.

I have just come back from southern Africa—Zimbabwe, Namibia and South Africa. I met someone who is now a minister in the Zimbabwean government but who had been in gaol for 14-odd years and had been tortured. One of the first things he did on becoming a minister was to promote one of the people who had been his torturers. Those southern African countries have a different attitude from ours to reconciliation. We need to take the politics out of reconciliation and get some meaningful reconciliation activity going, because it does not seem to be happening at the moment.

We have a fundamental structural problem, whether it is in the white or the black community. For instance, we do not seem to be talking about major problems within the community. We talk about the end result but we do not want to talk about alcohol and the problems it creates; instead we talk about other problems that are created by alcohol. But there is a serious problem with alcohol within the community. I think there is only one rehabilitation centre in the Northern Territory, and that one has just lost its funding. If we are really serious about addressing this issue we should be looking at the causes rather than the cures.

There is not much talk about AIDS within the Aboriginal community, but it is a growing problem. As well, the occurrence of STDs in the Aboriginal community is a major health problem, yet no-one seems to want to address it in any serious sense.

I call upon all governments, federal and state—perhaps even local governments—to become more serious about Aboriginal issues and to become actively involved, not just pay them lip service. I agree with the member for Moreton, who spoke of encouraging Aboriginal people to be part of the decision making and planning processes. It is no good going to them with plans and saying, `This is what we want you to do' and making a decision on it. We need fundamental planning processes coming from Aboriginal people so that we can actually help them to determine better what happens to them.

But this is not only an issue for governments. It also requires Aboriginal organisations to get actively involved in order to allow some of the things to happen, for instance, Ninga Mia. We have all been to Ninga Mia, although we did not visit there this time. To allow such things to happen is just appalling and we should really all be working together to resolve them. We are not really serious about the issues at the moment, and we really have to get serious about them.

I think the report is a good one and it contains a very solid 90 recommendations. The member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell) has done an excellent job. She has been very passionate about the issue and that shows in the reporting process. I hope that governments and other organisations take the recommendations seriously and act upon them, unlike current media reports. I commend the report to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brown The Hon R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I commend the members of the Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs who have already spoken on the committee's report Justice under scrutiny. Anyone wanting to find evidence of the bipartisan nature of that committee and its inquiry and report need look no further than the comments made by members of the committee from both sides of the House.

PARA.TAB: To a large extent the report speaks for itself. There is very little that can be added to it, but there are a few points I want to make. To my mind, Justice under scrutiny is probably one of the most honourable exercises that I have been involved in as a member of this parliament. There is nothing more honourable for a person to be involved in than the pursuit of the elimination of injustice and inequalities, which, to a very large extent, underlies the matter that was addressed by the royal commissioner in the inquiry into and report on Aboriginal deaths in custody. The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs was asked to report on the implementation by governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and this report, Justice under scrutiny, is the result of that inquiry.

TAB.EMPHASIS: A division having been called in the House of Representatives—

TALK.START.PARA: —As we left to go to the division in the main chamber, I was referring to the fact that there are 90 recommendations in this report. That follows the royal commission report which contained 339 recommendations, 338 of which were adopted by this parliament. In that context, one would have been perfectly entitled to expect that in the process of examining the implementation of the recommendations everything would have come up looking good, but that was not the case.

PARA.TAB: I want to refer particularly to the members of the subcommittee who participated in that and to the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell), who acted as chair of the subcommittee. All committee members applied themselves in the way that I suppose we should expect members of parliament to apply themselves to the tasks that they have, but there is no question that these members did more than that. I would also like to mention our appreciation for the work of Allan Kelly and Craig Dukes, in particular, and their colleagues in the secretariat for their assistance during the inquiry and in the completion of the report.

I commend the report to anyone who is concerned about the factors that gave rise to the royal commission and all of the factors that lie behind those depressing circumstances. There are probably too many separate elements to make reference to but I will mention a couple of things. When we are seeking to ensure that Aboriginal Australians are not incarcerated to the disproportionate extent that they are—in police custody, police cells, lock-ups or whatever—we need to look at all of the circumstances.

There are situations where police officers find their incomes significantly increased if they place Aboriginals in town lock-ups: it is known as a meal allowance. We have suggested that that should be abolished. It should never have existed. The amount to which some police officers have had their incomes enhanced as a result of that practice is significant. It has resulted in their earning in excess of twice what they would have earned in their basic salary.

We are concerned that funds allocated for specific purposes arising out of the royal commission report have been used for purposes other than those for which they were made available. We are concerned that some of the funds that were to assist in preventing the incarceration of Aboriginal people, and everything else that then gives rise to, were used to paint, improve and renovate police stations.

One of the other things that caused a lot of concern was the fact that, because Aboriginal people are disproportionately incarcerated, they get long lists of offences against their name. One of the offences is the `trifecta.' At one time, it was illegal for a person to be intoxicated in public. That has been eliminated, but it is now an offence to drink alcohol in a public place. If someone is drinking in a public place, and is apprehended by the police, it is possible that they will respond. If they do, they will find themselves charged with offensive behaviour. In the process of them saying, `No, don't arrest me, I haven't done anything wrong' they are resisting arrest. If they push the policeman, they are then guilty of assaulting a police officer. That is what is know as the `trifecta.' Some of these people have literally pages of those offences recorded against them.

The essential purpose should be to reduce the incarceration of Aboriginals. The fact is that the death rate of Aboriginals per 100 incarcerated Aboriginals is not significantly greater, and is in some cases less, than the death rates of non-Aboriginals per 100 of those prisoners. The thing that makes the difference is the disproportionately high number of Aboriginals who are themselves incarcerated, and everything that lies behind that.

I want to summarise the situation with a comment that was made by Mr and Mrs Murray when the committee met with the Deaths in Custody Watch Committee in Sydney. Mr and Mrs Murray are the parents of Edward James Murray, who on 12 June 1981 was found dead, hung by a strip of blanket made into a noose, in a police cell in the Wee Waa police station. He was 21. We were concerned at that time about the amount of counselling which had taken place as a result of funds that were made available for counselling. Let me get this on the Hansard record today. These people were asked what they would like to say about counselling. Mrs Murray replied:

SPEECH.PARA: I do not need counselling. My family does not need counselling. We only want justice in this country. That is the only counselling we need.
Her husband said:
Madam Chairman, if I may say so, I definitely can speak for each and every family that has lost someone in custody. I feel that a word like `counselling' to that family is insulting.
He said later:
I do not want some psych coming into my mind. I am not a mentally ill black fellow. All I want is one thing: justice.
Of course they are entitled to justice, and they are entitled to expect it from this parliament.

PARA.TAB: I was concerned that there were some responses that were being made by people before they had read the report. It is obvious that some of those people who have made the responses have not read the report. I would appeal to them in a spirit of goodwill to do so, and not to damn the report and not to damn people associated with that inquiry before they read the report. We did not find it very comfortable to find points to criticise about the federal government, federal authorities and instrumentalities, and federal policies. We did not find it very comfortable either to do the same thing with our state colleagues. I know the same thing applies to members of the opposition in connection with conservative state governments. But one thing we were charged to do was to investigate and report on the implementation of those recommendations. That was the charge that we had and that was the charge that we sought to fulfil, and we did it well.

Police Commissioner Jim O'Sullivan, in Brisbane, was reported as saying that he was `offended' and `extremely upset' by the committee's finding that deeply entrenched racist attitudes were held in the service, and as saying, `I totally reject this finding.' Also, he was reported in the Australian as having said, `We do not tolerate that type of attitude in our service.' In a summary of Australian news, the same fellow was reported as saying—and I would ask him in a spirit of goodwill whether he does not understand that this comment of his is racist based—`I wonder how many law-abiding citizens within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community were interviewed.' He is quoted as having said that. What is the implication of that? It is that most Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders are criminals, most of them are not law-abiding and the only ones that we saw were people who were offenders. That is not correct.

I just want to complete the comment with this: the whole process is continuing. I refer to `Murphy's Law', a column in the Sun-Herald, a Sydney Sunday paper, where the following appeared in reference to the act of urinating:

SPEECH.PARA: White folks relieving themselves has always been good for a giggle in this column. Last year we told you how a Wollongong beak—
that is, a magistrate—
dismissed it as a "piddling offence".
Listen to the difference, though, when it involves an Aboriginal kid:

It was no laughing matter for a 17-year-old Aborigine who was brought before Dubbo Children's Court recently charged with urinating on a white man's lawn in a NSW country town. As the shaken youth sat in court, Legal Service lawyer Mark Dennis said his client "has spent 20 hours in custody and has been dragged to court across many kilometres of winding country road in handcuffs in the back of a wagon holding on to the internal wire mesh so that he does not fall and injure himself."

The royal commission had demanded before that a juvenile should only be detained in exceptional circumstances. What did the courts do to this kid? They imposed $1,000 bail on him, which was impossible to meet. If he could not meet it, he stayed in custody.

PARA.TAB: Mr Dennis, the chap from the legal service, described the treatment of the youth as evil and disgraceful. He asked the magistrate to send a clear message to the town police in relation to this matter. He said they had abused their power and the processes of the court and that the refusal of bail was small-minded and vindictive. In connection with the police, he said: they are not a service; they are a force, and a force of which society should be ashamed. The magistrate dismissed the charge, as he should have done.

The point that I make in raising that is to indicate that it continues. Those people who were sensitive in Queensland—Mr Braddy and Mr O'Sullivan—made not very generous responses, particularly to two of their colleagues who are honourable members of this place and dedicated, conscientious members. One of them is the chairman of the full committee, the other one is the chairman of the sub-committee, and they are entitled to more consideration and a little more respect for their effort, their conscientious approach to the question and the principles which they so courageously display.

If Queensland thinks we singled it out, we did no such thing. We referred to ourselves as well. There is an example of something in New South Wales—my state. Are people suggesting to us that there is no entrenched racism in New South Wales when they treat a 17-year-old Aboriginal kid in the way I have described? It is a piddling offence if a white man urinates. It is matter of grave concern involving $1,000 cash bail, incarceration and humiliation for a black 17-year-old kid if he urinates. If we want any further confirmation of the need for the recommendations to be put into place, the report indicates the need and the comments that have been made by our good colleagues on both sides of the parliament, in confirming those recommendations, provide more evidence than we should ever need.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Nugent Mr P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is very interesting to note the reaction to the Report on implementation of governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody, particularly from Queensland. I support those comments made by the honourable member for Charlton (Mr Robert Brown) concerning New South Wales. I noticed in the papers this morning that, in my state of Victoria, the state minister was moved to say that, yes, at long last this week the Victorian parliament would get around to tabling its rather tardy response to the royal commission findings and its progress. It may be an accident of timing, but it seems a pity that a report which is as sweeping and condemning as this report about government action at all levels has to come out before governments start to do just the basics that they are required to do under the agreement that they have voluntarily entered into.

PARA.TAB: This report is nearly 400 pages and it has 90 recommendations. I came relatively late to this inquiry, having rejoined the committee only a short time ago. I was not directly involved in

SPEECH.PARA: many of its findings. I say that not to absolve myself of any responsibility, but to make it quite clear that I cannot claim too much credit for this report. I would like to acknowledge the work that the committee has done. It has done a very difficult thing in very trying circumstances and has come up with a fine report.

PARA.TAB: I speak with some knowledge on these matters, having been for three years a member—in fact, the deputy chair—of this committee between 1990 and 1993, having been the shadow minister for a time whilst this inquiry was going on, and having been for three years a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. My travels around the country have enabled me to see and hear first-hand many of the things that have been produced in evidence in this report.

I hesitate to break the mood of all of us saying how those people out there are terrible and how good a job we have done, but what this tome tells me is that perhaps the Attorney-General (Mr Lavarch) and the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs (Mr Tickner) need to re-examine the policies that they are adopting in terms of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issues. Whilst I do not dispute in any sense the good intentions of those two ministers in this respect, nevertheless it is important that we recognise that the policies that have been put in place in the last two or three years, on the evidence that is here, are patently not working. And we perhaps need a new approach.

Let us be quite clear that in this country the federal government has responsibility in this country for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, and the 1967 referendum gave it that responsibility quite specifically. The government has been very loud in its protestations about what a wonderful record it has, how it is doing the right thing and how it is proud of its achievements. But the evidence in this report has been about for a long time, and the country—and the government in particular—have failed to resolve the problems.

The royal commission gave us all the evidence that was needed, and we have had a string of reports from House of Representatives committees, on which many of the members present have served. The human rights commission has produced further reports. So the evidence has been ongoing for some years as to what is wrong and the fact that existing programs, procedures and structures are failing to deal adequately with the issues that are afflicting the indigenous people of this country.

The federal government will tell us that we have a problem with the federalist system; the states have a lot of responsibility, and of course that is right. But equally the federal government provides most of the money, which is a very useful and clear way in which to exercise control. Obviously, the states have a large slice of responsibility but the federal government has the prime responsibility. This report tells us that all indicators show that we are seeing very limited, if any, improvement in most of the issues that were identified by the royal commission. There are some improvements but not a great number.

I could go through the findings in some detail, but I think that has probably been done fairly exhaustively by other members of the committee. It may be noteworthy to say a couple of things about the actual findings. In the executive summary of the committee's report I draw attention to the sentence:

SPEECH.PARA: The committee was keen to ensure that the Royal Commission report and its recommendations is not allowed to gather dust on a shelf.

I for one will make sure if I possibly can that we keep this subject before the public in the coming years—whichever party is in power and whether it is the federal government or the state governments involved.

PARA.TAB: The committee has also gone into some detail in terms of the ATSIC monitoring unit. It seems to me that the ATSIC monitoring unit has not been successful in what it was set up to do. I am not going to attack individuals, but it seems to me that the bottom line—whether we like it or not—is that the monitoring unit has not done the job that we hoped it would. If we say that, it is therefore important to acknowledge that, if it has failed and there do not appear to be easy ways to fix those problems, something has to be done. The committee has gone to some lengths to suggest a process for that to happen.

In that context, I would like to give a message to the ATSIC commissioners. One of the criticisms I have of ATSIC commissioners is that over the last couple of years they have been all too defensive when people have tried to make constructive suggestions about the way that ATSIC has performed. It is not a question of attacking ATSIC. It is not a question of trying to do it down, or denigrate the process, or suggest that ATSIC is the wrong vehicle. All bureaucratic organisations—and ATSIC has its share of bureaucracy, the same as any other organisation—have their problems and ATSIC must expect to be accountable to the parliament. If the parliament asks questions and makes criticisms from time to time, ATSIC should be big enough to take those constructive criticisms on board. I would ask the ATSIC commissioners not to be ultra-defensive about the comments of the committee in regard to the monitoring unit; and to accept them in the spirit in which they are made, which is to try to improve the system for the benefit of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

We have seen varying responses from the states, both to this report and to the previous royal commission report. Some have obviously responded better than others and I would hope that we can encourage all of them to lift their game. It is also important that a brief comment be made on the tardiness of action that we have seen in areas such as the recognition of Aboriginal customary laws. The Australian Law Reform Commission released its report on the recognition of Aboriginal customary law in 1986. We are nearly a decade on from that and we are still talking about the need to do something about recognising customary law. We are still talking about the need to recognise the differences in culture which account for many of the problems in this country in respect of indigenous people.

We still have quite disgraceful statistics in terms of imprisonment: there is an over-representation of indigenous people in custody. In 1994, an Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander person is still 19.4 times more likely to be locked up. That is a national disgrace. This is two years on from the royal commission. But it is 10 years on from when everybody recognised that it was the case. I believe that the minister and the Attorney-General should be much more pro-active in trying to redress those injustices at COAG and through other mechanisms. I do not think that it is sufficient to give this problem to the bureaucrats. There has to be the political will. In that sense, I would have to say that I am critical of the minister and the Attorney-General.

The bad performance of the police is not the only reason that people are in gaol. There are all those other socio-economic factors. It is not necessary to be an Aboriginal; one can be an East German, or a Bosnian, or from some other country around the world where the pigmentation of the skin may be totally different. But if people have to endure appalling health, appalling housing, poor education and unemployment, they will get into trouble with the law and will be over-represented in gaol. We need to see much more done to address those basic issues, which is what justice and equity ought to be about in this country.
Finally, I wish to refer to the executive summary that the committee has issued. I would like to quote that section where the committee talks about young Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is concerned that there is too much emphasis on bureaucratic responses to the problems faced by indigenous youth and that there is not enough emphasis on community programs and solutions. The Committee is concerned that the government implementation reports it received outlined bureaucratic activity with insufficient attention paid to the delivery of services and the outcomes for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. They frequently involved a glossing over of the deficiencies in implementation rather than a critical evaluation of the processes. The committee found numerous examples of gross failures to implement the Royal Commission recommendations with crucial funding being used for internal bureaucratic conferences and meetings rather than community consultations and program delivery.

I have to say that this is often the case in many areas where money is allocated for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander affairs. It applies to white bureaucrats and black bureaucrats, right across the spectrum of federal and state government, and it is a major weakness in the system.

PARA.TAB: As I say, we need to quite clearly change the monitoring process. I support the recommendations made by the committee in that respect. It is unfortunate, perhaps, that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Human Rights Commissioner, who it is proposed should control that method, is actually a government appointee. But I have to say, knowing Mick Dodson, that I think he has the personal character and strength of will to deal with the issues honestly, openly and fearlessly when he sees them. So I do not think we need to worry too much on that score.

It is not only a question of monitoring more effectively. It is actually a question of trying to make sure that our programs in health, housing, education and so on are much better directed. It seems to me that state governments have to lift their game, the federal government has to lift its game, and so does ATSIC. Indigenous people must be more involved in the process. ATSIC is not sufficient, in my view, because it is not representative of the whole community. It may have the geographic spread but it only has 30-odd per cent of people voting for it. Many indigenous people out there will say that they do not believe ATSIC speaks for them. We have to have a wider input into the system.

I think we have to look at customary law. I think we have to look at cultural differences. And we have to get our house in order because it is right to do so for our indigenous people. But if we do not want to take a—if you like—moral stance, in terms of doing what is right for fellow Australians, let us do it if only to get our house in order in our international sense. How can we criticise the Indonesians? The chairman of this committee does that regularly—and good luck to him, and good strength to him. He will never get a ministry, of course, but he is right in what he says.

How can we go into international forums if we do not have our own house in order? In the Great Hall on Tuesday night Archbishop Tutu said that we have to address these issues. One of the frightening things I found yesterday was when, as a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation and with three or four other members of that council, I met members of the visiting South African parliamentary delegation. They had already met the minister and heard what we were doing. We explained what we were doing with the reconciliation process, and their attitude was—this was from coloured members of the delegation—we think you are setting up an apartheid system. That is a very sobering thought that perhaps the committee might want to give more attention to.

Aboriginal people are angry, and rightly so, because there is no improvement. The wider community is angry because of wasted resources and no improvement. Let us be quite clear. It is not the Native Title Act that is going to fix these things, or the land fund—although they are all necessary. The problem lies with the will by government to get on with it. This government has had 10 years. It has to be more direct in the action it is taking because so far we have only scratched the surface.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Scott Mr L.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to use the remaining time available to correct something in relation to the public response so far to the Report on implementation of governments of the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. I would like to commend those who have been associated with this report. I have been associated with it, but I particularly want to commend the chair of the committee—the member for Capricornia (Ms Henzell)—and all the staff involved in putting it together. It is sad that we actually have to do a report like this, and it just indicates that things are not happening out there in relation to implementing the recommendations of the royal commission.

PARA.TAB: Most people out there would know that, but I was very offended by the public response by some people in my own state of Queensland. I have lived in Queensland all my life and I know the problems there. Anyone who has lived in that state for any length of time can see the problems there and our inquiry just homed in on that. But I was particularly concerned that the police minister in Queensland, Mr Paul Braddy, called this a shoddy and silly report and made allegations against members of the committee. He said:

SPEECH.PARA: I think it's a shoddy report for which the backbenchers should be condemned and if they repeat that sort of work, the people who wrote this report will remain backbenchers for the rest of their careers.

To attack us like that is grossly unfair. It almost borders on a matter of privilege that a state government colleague is attacking us for doing a report that has shown up a lot of problems out there in the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community. I would call on Mr Braddy, quite frankly, to apologise to each and every one of the members of this committee for his allegations that were made without considering the report and all the ramifications of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —He hasn't even read the report.

—As the member for Moreton interjects, he has obviously not read the report and has no real commitment to what we are trying to correct in this country. We need the support of the state governments and it is about time that they all got together to work with us in fixing this national disgrace and to really make sure that the recommendations from the royal commission are implemented to the benefit of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people.

PARA.TAB: Debate (on motion by Ms Henzell) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answers to questions were circulated:

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 1 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: Was it necessary to modify the curtain wall in the new Australian Taxation Office Building at Belconnen, ACT; if so, (a) why, (b) what was the original cost of the curtain wall before its modification, (c) what is the curtain wall and (d) what is its purpose.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Yes.

(a) The curtain wall on the ATO office building in Belconnen did require modification as its original design did not take into account two areas of the building which were designed with a deflection greater than the average.
(b) The original tender price for the curtain wall was $4.439 million.
(c) The curtain wall is an aluminium facade system which forms the external `skin' of the building.
(d) The purpose of the curtain wall is to provide a thermally efficient weatherproof skin to the building structure.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Assistant Treasurer upon notice, on 19 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: Will the Government restrict foreign ownership in companies given the oversubscription in some share floats?

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: No, the Government has no intention of changing its basic stance on foreign investment in Australia as a reaction to the oversubscription of a few public share floats. A more restrictive foreign investment policy might prejudice a successful outcome to future floats.

Foreign ownership is already restricted in some circumstances. The Government's foreign investment policy is framed and administered with a view to encouraging foreign investment in Australia, while ensuring that such investment is consistent with the needs of the community. Under the Government's foreign investment policy, there are restrictions on foreign investment in sensitive sectors, namely the media, civil aviation, banking and real estate sectors.

For the non-sensitive sectors (including manufacturing, mining and services sectors), takeovers of existing Australian businesses with total assets less than $5 million and the establishment of new businesses involving total investment of less than $10 million are exempt from notification. Purchases of rural businesses valued at less than $3 million are also exempt. The Government registers, but normally raises no objections to proposals above these thresholds where the relevant total assets/total investment fall below $50 million. Examinable proposals to acquire existing businesses or to establish new businesses are assessed against a "contrary to the national interest" test. Investors can expect that approval will not be withheld on national interest grounds other than in unusual circumstances affecting Australia's vital interests and development. Portfolio investments normally are not covered by Australia's foreign investment policy.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 22 September 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Which agency collects the financial institutions duty (FID).
(2) How is the FID collected.
(3) To what type of transactions does the FID relate.
(4) At what rate is the FID set.
(5) What revenue was collected from the FID in each year since it was introduced.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's questions is as follows:

PARA.TAB: Financial institutions duties (FIDs) are imposed and administered by all States and Territories except Queensland. Whilst the Commonwealth has, through various reports available to it, some information on the operation and rates of FID this information is not sufficiently comprehensive to enable a full and accurate response to the questions asked.

The honourable member should therefore direct his questions to the relevant State and Territory governments. I might also direct the honourable member to a recent article which appeared in `Australian Tax Forum, A Journal of Taxation Policy, Law and Reform', Vol. 10 entitled Finance Taxes in Australia which examined FIDs.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Department of Administrative Services: Liaison Officers

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Human Services and Health, upon notice, on 12 October 1994:

PARA.TAB: (1) Is excimer laser surgery to correct myopia deemed to be cosmetic surgery and not a medical procedure; if so, why.
(2) Is it a fact that many persons are inhibited in various activities by spectacles and contact lenses and find excimer laser surgery necessary.
(3) Will the Government reconsider the classification of excimer laser surgery with a view to assisting patients for it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

PARA.TAB: (1), (2) & (3) I assume that the honourable member's question relates to the non-inclusion of an item relating to the treatment of myopia using excimer laser surgery in the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS) for the purpose of the payment of Medicare benefits. New services are generally included in the MBS only after their clinical efficacy, and cost benefit, have been established. In this regard, the Government obtains expert advice, including advice from the relevant professional College, which in relation to eye pathology is the Royal Australian College of Ophthalmology.

It should be noted that in June 1993 the National Health and Medical Research Council reported that follow-up studies of laser corneal sculpting, such as that performed using the excimer laser, were ongoing and that long-term questions must be answered before the treatment could be recommended as a routine procedure. The Australian Health Technology Advisory Committee has also stated that spectacles and contact lenses provide the safest, most effective and affordable treatment for myopia.

While it is understood that almost all who have undergone excimer laser surgery have had reduced myopia, side effects such as regression, over-correction, erosion and scarring of the cornea, sensitivity to glare and corneal haze have been reported. It would be inappropriate to include this procedure in the MBS until its clinical efficacy and cost benefit have been established.
